questions.text: Which of the following is false regarding gastrointestinal stromal tumor (GIST)?

choices.text: Originates from interstitial cells of Cajal

questions.solution:
GISTs metastasize more commonly via haematogenous route.

Gastrointestinal stromal tumor:

  • M/C mesenchymal tumor of GIT arising from interstitial cells of Cajal (ICC).
  • Almost all GISTs express c-KIT (CD117), PDGF receptor A, CD34.
  • M/C site - stomach.
  • IOC for primary GIST- CT scan.
  • IOC for recurrent GIST-  PET-CT.
  • Route of metastasis – Hematogenous.
  • Treatment - Resection with negative margin.
  • Chemotherapy with imatinib, sunitinib.
  • Prognosis – mainly depends on tumor size.

questions.text: Interstitial fluid volume can be calculated by ________

choices.text: Using radiolabeled water and 133I labeled albumin

questions.solution:
• The interstitial fluid volume is measured by subtracting plasma volume from extracellular fluid (ECF) volume, i.e., ISF = ECF – Plasma.
  • Hence, for measuring ISF we must measure both ECF and plasma.
  • ECF is measured by:
    • Inulin (best method)
    • 22Na
    • 125I-iothalamate
    • Thiosulfate
    • Mannitol
    • Sucrose
  • Plasma is measured by:
    • 125I-albumin (most commonly used)
    • Evans blue dye (T-1824)
Compartment   Indicator used
Plasma volume   Evans blue (T1824). 125I-albumin (most commonly used)
RBC volume Tagging RBC with 51Cr, 59Fe, 32P, also antigenic tagging 
Total blood volume Plasma volume/(1-Hematocrit)
ECF volume Inulin, sucrose, mannitol, sodium thiosulphate, sodium thiocyanate, 22Na, 125I-iothalamate
Interstitial fluid   Cannot be measured directly.  Calculated as ECF-Plasma
ICF volume Cannot be measured directly.  Can be calculated as Total body water – ECF 
Total body water   D20 (most frequently used), tritium oxide, antipyrine

questions.text: A 30-year-old man presents with silvery-white scaly lesions on the extensor aspect of the elbows and knee. The clinical diagnosis is assisted by ______.
questions.solution:
The presence of silvery-white scaly lesions on the extensor aspect of the elbows and knee is a characteristic feature seen in psoriasis. The condition can be diagnosed clinically by demonstrating the Auspitz sign.

Auspitz sign is due to the elongated vessels in the dermal papilla which are under the thin supra papillary epidermis.

Demonstration of Auspitz Sign:
If superficial silvery scales are removed by scratching (grattage), then the scales come off attached together, as if one has scratched on a wax candle (wax candle scales).

Subsequently, a thin membrane, known as Bulkeley membrane is seen. Removal of Bulkeley membrane reveals classical pinpoint bleeding known as the Auspitz sign.

Silvery-white scales on the extensor aspect of the elbow seen in psoriasis are portrayed in the picture below:

questions.text: An unconscious diabetic is brought to the ER. His medical records show he is on warfarin for atrial fibrillation. Which of the following investigations will not be done in this patient for workup?
questions.solution:
• Lumbar puncture is contraindicated in patients with bleeding diathesis/novel anticoagulants.
  • The most common site of bleeding after lumbar puncture in patients on anticoagulants is epidural space.
  • This leads to neurological complications and poor response to surgery. 
  • Random blood sugar is done for evaluating non-ketotic hyperosmolar coma versus hypoglycemia as cause of unconsciousness. 
  • ECG is done for evaluating atrial fibrillation and hence embolic stroke 
  • Non-contrast CT is done for the possibility of atherosclerosis and stroke.

questions.text: Injury to the membranous urethra leads to accumulation of urine in _______:
questions.solution:
Injury to the membranous urethra (content of deep perineal pouch) leads to accumulation of urine in the deep perineal pouch.

Injury to the spongy urethra leads to the accumulation of urine in the superficial perineal pouch. Since the superficial perineal fascia (Colles’ fascia) is in continuity with Scarpa’s fascia of the anterior abdominal wall and the fascial layer that contains the dartos muscle, urine can accumulate in the scrotum, perineum and lower abdominal wall.

questions.text: A patient gives chronic history of diarrhea and blood in stool presents with multiple fistulae in the perineum and multiple strictures in small intestine. The diagnosis is __________
questions.solution:
Inflammatory bowel disease (IBD) is an immune-mediated chronic intestinal condition. Ulcerative colitis (UC) and Crohn’s disease (CD) are the two major types of IBD.

Crohn’s disease:-

  • Macroscopic features:
    • Distribution is segmental with skip areas.
    • Involves mainly terminal ileum and ascending colon.
    • Involves entire thickness of affected segment of bowel wall.
    • Serpiginous ulcers that may develop into deep fissures.
    • Shortening of bowel wall due to fibrosis.
  • Microscopic features:
    • Transmural inflammation.
    • Non caseating granulomas and infiltrate of mononuclear cells (lymphocytes, plasma cells and macrophages).
    • Patchy ulceration in mucosa.
    • Fibrosis present.
  • Clinical features:
    • Usual presentation is that of ileocolitis with a chronic history of recurrent episodes of right lower quadrant pain and diarrhea.
    • An inflammatory mass may be palpated in the right lower quadrant of the abdomen. The mass is composed of inflamed bowel, adherent and indurated mesentery, and enlarged abdominal lymph nodes.
    • Jejunoileitis causes malabsorption and steatorrhea .
    • Colitis present with low-grade fevers, malaise, diarrhea, crampy abdominal pain, and sometimes hematochezia. Gross bleeding is not as common as in UC, only 1–2% bleed massively.
    • ASCA positive.

questions.text: During autopsy, stomach is opened along the ________

choices.text: Lesser curvature, from cardiac to pyloric end
Lesser curvature, from pyloric to cardiac end
Greater curvature, from cardiac to pyloric end
Greater curvature, from pyloric to cardiac end

questions.solution: During autopsy, stomach is opened along greater curvature, from its cardiac end to pyloric end.

questions.text: Maintenance dose of a drug primarily depends upon _________
questions.solution:
The maintenance dose of a drug primarily depends upon clearance (or plasma half-life) of the drug. It is the dose that has to be repeated at specified intervals after the attainment of the target plasma concentration, in order to maintain it.

Other options:

Option A: The loading dose of the drug is primarily dependent on the volume of distribution. 

Options C and D: Volume of distribution (Vd) refers to the volume that would accommodate the entire drug in the body if the concentration was the same as in plasma. Vd is governed by the lipid solubility and charge of the drug, the degree of the plasma protein binding, and the affinity of the drug for the different tissues of the body.  A low Vd is seen with drugs that have extensive plasma protein binding and vice versa.

questions.text: The egg shown in the image below belongs to __________
questions.solution:
The image shows a bile stained egg of whipworm.

Egg of whipworm (Trichuris trichiura) is barrel shaped in the middle with a projecting mucus plug at each pole containing a non-segmented ovum. The plugs are colorless.

The egg has a triple shell, the outermost layer of which is stained brown

The eggs float in saturated salt solution.

Eggs are not infective for humans.

Related Pearl: Parasites with bile-stained eggs

The following are the parasites with bile-stained eggs. (mnemonic: FaT CAT)

  • Fasciola hepatica (sheep liver fluke)
  • Fasciolopsis buski (giant intestinal fluke)
  • Trichuris trichiura (whipworm)
  • Clonorchis sinensis (chinese liver fluke, oriental liver fluke)
  • Ascaris lumbricoides (round worm)
  • Taenia solium (pork tapeworm)
  • Taenia saginata (beef tapeworm)

Related Pearl: Eggs in parasitology

questions.text: Where is the collection of pus formed in quinsy?
questions.solution:
Quinsy is also called peritonsillar abscess.

It is the collection of pus between the fibrous capsule of the tonsil and the superior constrictor muscles of the pharynx.

Etiology

  • anaerobic bacteria and
  • beta-hemolytic streptococci
  • related to periodontal disease.

Clinical features

  • sore throat,
  • dysphagia,
  • drooling of saliva,
  • trismus,
  • ipsilateral otalgia,
  • fever with headache

Antibiotics and needle aspiration are commonly used as treatment modalities.

questions.text: Sentinel lymph node biopsy is most useful in which of the following gynecological malignancies?
questions.solution:
Among the given gynecological malignancies, sentinel lymph node biopsy (SLNB) is most useful in vulval carcinomas.

This is because women with earlier stages of vulval cancer can have diseased lymph nodes even without palpable enlargement of nodes. Hence, sentinel lymph node biopsy helps in early diagnosis lymph node spread which can be managed by lymph node dissection.

A sentinel lymph node is a physiologically, the first lymph node to receive tumor lymphatic drainage.

Malignancies where sentinel lymph node biopsy is commonly done are :

  • Vulval carcinoma
  • Breast carcinoma
  • Penile carcinoma
  • Malignant melanoma

Lymphatic mapping is similar technique to SLNB that can also be used in vulval cancers.

questions.text: A 10-year-old boy comes with complaints of diminished vision. On examination, the macula shows a ‘beaten-bronze’ appearance. Furthermore, visual fields show a central loss. The choroid is characteristically ‘dark’ in fluorescein angiography. All of the following about this disease are true except:

choices.text: Vitamin A supplementation should be given
Accumulation of lipofuscin within retinal pigment epithelium
It is inherited in autosomal recessive pattern

questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario suggests a diagnosis of Stargardt disease. Vitamin A supplementation is avoided as it may accelerate lipofuscin accumulation.

Stargardt disease/ fundus flavimaculatus is the most common type of macular dystrophy occurring in childhood or adolescence. It is commonly inherited in an autosomal recessive pattern due to mutation in the ABCA4 gene. It is characterized by the accumulation of lipofuscin within the retinal pigment epithelium(RPE). 

Macular signs

  • May initially be normal, later progressing to an oval ‘snail slime’ or ‘beaten-bronze’ appearance and subsequently to geographic atrophy.
  • Numerous yellow-white round, oval or fish-shaped lesions at the level of the RPE.

Investigations:

  • Visual fields show a central loss.
  • Electroretinography - Pattern ERG is completely extinguished while full-field ERG may remain normal.
  • FFA- Dark choroid, the macula shows mixed hyper and hypofluorescence.
  • Indocyanine green angiography (ICGA) shows hyperfluorescent spots.

Image A shows the fundus with macular yellow flecks and B shows the angiofluoresceingraphy (AFG) of the silent choroid and atrophic retinal pigment epithelium at the macular area.

questions.text: Antenatal USG in a primigravida revealed fetal hydrocephalus. Postnatal MRI of the infant is shown below. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given T2 MRI image shows the racing car appearance, which is seen in agenesis of the corpus callosum. This sign refers to the widely spaced lateral ventricles with intervening Probst bundles(white matter tracts that are no longer able to cross the midline in the corpus callosum).

Appearances on axial MRI or CT resemble a Formula One car seen from above. The front tyres are represented by the widely spaced frontal horns anteriorly. The back tyres are represented by the dilated trigones seen posteriorly, which is also known as colpocephaly.

The image given below shows the racing car sign in corpus callosal agensis.

Other options:

Option B: Marchiafava - Bignami disease is a rare condition characterized by demyelination of the corpus callosum most often in patients with chronic alcoholism. The MRI image in this condition shows the sandwich sign.

 

Option C: Metachromatic leukodystrophy is an autosomal-recessive disease that results from a deficiency of the lysosomal enzyme arylsulfatase A. Symmetric confluent areas of T2 hyperintensity are seen in the periventricular white matter. Radiating T2 hypointense lines through the demyelinated deep white matter represent the sparing of the perivascular white matter. This results in the tigroid and leopard skin patterns when imaged in the long axis or cross-section, respectively. Subcortical U-fibers are spared.

Option D: The most common site of lipoma in the brain is the peri-callosal region. The CT below shows bracket calcification of lipoma and is called bracket sign.

questions.text: Hangman fracture involves fracture of C2 through the __________
questions.solution:
Hangman fracture involves fracture of the axis (C2) through the pars interarticularis or isthmic portion.
It is also called traumatic spondylolisthesis of the axis.
It usually occurs through hyperextension and axial loading, although some patterns of this fracture may involve flexion as well.
The types of hangman fracture are given below:

Hangman fracture types  Mechanism of injury  Comments  Treatment  
Type I Hyperextension. Minimal displacement and no kyphosis through disc space. No ligamentous injuries.  Rigid collar. 
Type II Hyperextension and axial loading followed by flexion.  Fracture line is vertical and there is at least 3mm translation through the disc space.  Traction and then halo vest for 12 weeks. 
Type III Flexion compression injuries along with traumatic spndylolisthesis.  Dislocation of C2-C3 facet occurs.  Open reduction of dislocation. 

Types I, II and III of hangman fracture are shown in the images below:

questions.text: A baby is brought to the OPD with complaints of lethargy and poor feeding. On examination, it is noted that the urine had a smell of burnt sugar. A defect in which of the following enzymes causes this disease?
questions.solution:
The diagnosis, in this case, is that of maple syrup urine disease (MSUD). This disease occurs due to a defect of the enzyme branched-chain keto acid dehydrogenase.

 MSUD is an autosomal recessive disorder that occurs due to a deficiency of branched-chain ketoacid dehydrogenase complex. This impairs the metabolism of branched-chain amino acids valine, leucine, isoleucine, and alloisoleucine. These amino acids, particularly leucine and its metabolite accumulate in the blood, causing toxic effects on the brain.

The affected child develops poor feeding and vomiting a few days after birth. There is a period of hypertonicity with a period of flaccidity in between. These appear as repetitive boxing and bicycling movements. The babies may also have hypoglycemia, but this is not corrected by the administration of glucose. The urine, sweat, and cerumen of the baby have a sweetish maple syrup-like odor.

Laboratory investigations will show increased levels of branched-chain amino acids in the plasma and urine. Leucine levels are usually higher than isoleucine, valine, and alloisoleucine. Since the patient excretes ketone bodies in the urine, the urine will be positive for the dinitrophenylhydrazine test.

Treatment involves controlled intake of branched-chain amino acids using commercially available formulas and judicious supplementation of isoleucine and valine. Very high levels of leucine are removed by hemodialysis.

questions.text: The most characteristic finding of HIV in children is _________
questions.solution:
• Failure to thrive is the universal characteristic finding in HIV children.
  • Most common AIDS-defining illness in children is P. carinii pneumonia.
  • Most common fungal infection of HIV children is oral candidiasis.
  • Most common GI disease is chronic or recurrent diarrhea with malabsorption.
  • Most common hematological manifestation is anemia.
  • Most common renal disease is nephrotic syndrome.
  • Most common neoplasms are non-Hodgkin’s lymphoma, primary CNS lymphoma and leiomyosacomas.

questions.text: In patients administered thiopentone, which property of the drug allows for the rapid recovery from anesthesia?
questions.solution:
Rapid recovery from thiopentone anesthesia is due to its rapid redistribution.

It is redistributed from the brain to tissues that are less perfused, like muscles, resulting in rapid recovery (within 20 minutes).

questions.text: Physical symptoms in factitious disorder can be all of the following except:
questions.solution:
Physical symptoms in factitious disorder can be:

  • Fabricated (giving false history of diabetes or AIDS)
  • Feigned (pretending to have a seizure)
  • Induced (self-influcted)
  • Aggravated (by not allowing to heal or recover)

questions.text: A 35 year old athlete has height of 184cm, arm span of 194cm, pulse rate of 64/ min and BP of 148/64 mmHg. Chest auscultation reveals long diastolic murmur over right 2nd inter-costal space. The probable diagnosis is ______
questions.solution:
In this question, arm span being greater than height is suggestive of Marfan’s syndrome.

Marfan’s syndrome is a genetic disorder of the connective tissue due to mutation in the fibrillin gene (15q21).

  • Features of Marfans’s syndrome (Mnemonic: MARFAN’S)
    • Mitral valve prolapse
    • Myopia due to upward dislocation of lens (b/l ectopic lentis)
    • Aortic root dilatation
    • Aortic regurgitation ( Diastolic murmur in right second intercoastal space ).
    • Retinal detachment
    • Fibrillin 1 gene defect - Reduced fibrillin 1 production causing joint laxity
    • Fifteen (chromosome 15 is involved)
    • Flat feet
    • Arachnodactyly
    • Astigmatism
    • Air in lungs (Pneumothorax)
    • Near sightedness
    • Subluxation of lens
    • Scoliosis
    • Speech disorders
    • Sleep apnea
    • Spinal cord - dural ectasia
    • Steinberg thumb sign - thumb tip extends from palm of hand in a closed fist

questions.text: The least common site of ectopic parathyroid gland in patients with persistent or recurrent hyperparathyroidism is?
questions.solution:
• The least common site of ectopic parathyroid gland in recurrent HPT is high cervical or undescended (2%).
  • The most common sites of ectopic parathyroid glands in patients with persistent or recurrent HPT are:
    • Paraesophageal (28%)
    • Mediastinal (26%)
    • Intrathymic(24%)
    • Intrathyroidal (11%)
    • Carotid sheath (9%)
    • High cervical or undescended (2%)

questions.text: Following penicillin administration, a 45-year-old male has the pathological abnormality depicted in the laryngoscopy image below. Which of the following chemical mediators is most likely to be responsible?
questions.solution:
• Laryngeal edema seen in the image is due to preformed histamine which is released from mast cells in this form of anaphylaxis, which is a type 1 hypersensitivity reaction.
  • Systemic anaphylaxis, in some individuals, can induce a severe reaction that occurs within minutes, leading to symptomatology such as acute asthma, laryngeal edema, diarrhea, urticaria, and shock. Classic examples are penicillin allergy and bee sting allergy.

questions.text: Articular surfaces are biaxial and reciprocally concavo-convex in which type of joint?
questions.solution:
Saddle (Sellar Joints)

Articular surfaces are reciprocally concavoconvex. Movements are similar to those permitted by an ellipsoid joint.

  • Free movements are permitted around axes; flexion and extension around the transverse axis; and abduction and adduction around the antero-posterior axis.
  • Combination of movements produces circumduction.
  • In addition there is some rotation (conjunct rotation) around a third axis which, however, cannot occur independently.
  • Examples: First carpometacarpal joint, sternoclavicular joint.

questions.text: Regarding phenytoin, which of the following is false?

choices.text: At very low doses, zero order kinetics occurs
Higher the dose, higher is the half life

questions.solution:
• Phenytoin, at very low doses follows first order kinetics.
  • As the dose increases, the metabolizing enzymes get saturated and kinetics change to zero order.
  • Higher doses results in higher half life (Option C).
  • Phenytoin is highly protein bound (~90%) and induces microsomal enzymes (Options A and D).

questions.text: All of the following are true about Klumpke’s palsy except:

choices.text: It is an upper brachial plexus injury
Association with Horner’s syndrome can be seen in avulsing injuries
Motor and Association with Horner’s syndrome can be seen in avulsing injuries sensory deficits involving C8 and T1
Can be caused by trauma from crutches

questions.solution:
• Klumpke’s palsy is caused by lower brachial plexus injury.
  • Most lower plexus injuries are from penetrating wounds, difficult births, falling on outstretched arm and trauma from crutches.
  • There are usually motor and sensory deficits involving C8 and T1 with or without C7 dysfunction.
  • In case of an avulsing injury, Horner’s syndrome may be associated with this condition.
  • There is paralysis of the flexors of wrist and fingers.
  • Sensory deficit is along medial aspect of arm, forearm and hand.

questions.text: Which of the following intrauterine infections is associated with limb reduction defects and scarring of skin?
questions.solution:
• Intrauterine infections associated with limb reduction defects and scarring of skin are associated with fetal varicella syndrome.

  • Fetal varicella infection occurs if maternal infection occurs during first half of pregnancy.
  • Its features include cicatrising skin lesions, micropthalmia, cataracts, optic atrophy, chorioretinitis, microcephaly, limb hypoplasia along with motor and sensory deficits.

questions.text: After-coming head of breech will have difficulty in delivery in all of the following conditions except __________:
questions.solution:
• Placenta previa is not a cause for the entrapment of the after-coming head.
  • Arrest of the after-coming head occurs in the following conditions.
    • At the brim: deflexed head, hydrocephalus, contracted pelvis
    • In the cavity: deflexed head, contracted pelvis
    • At the outlet: Deflexed head, rigid perineum
    • Incompletely dilated cervix: Premature baby, macerated baby, footling presentation, hasty delivery of breech before cervix is fully dilated.
  • Management:
    • Malar flexion and shoulder traction.
    • Duhressen's incision can be made at 2 and 10 O’ clock position on the cervix.
    • Zavanelli maneuver: replacement of fetus higher into the vagina and uterus, followed by a cesarean delivery.

questions.text: When NaCl is injected in the internal carotid artery it causes release of ADH by acting on __________
questions.solution:
• Vasopressin secretion is regulated by osmoreceptors located in the anterior hypothalamus. (Supraoptic nucleus) 
  • They are outside the blood-brain barrier and appear to be located in the circumventricular organs, primarily the organum vasculosum of the lamina terminalis (OVLT).
  • On injecting NaCl, there is increase in the osmolality.
  • Osmoreceptors have stimulatory action on thirst centre and ADH secreting supraoptic nucleus.

questions.text: Which of the following are membrane bound, pattern recognition receptors (PRRs)?
questions.solution:
The membrane-bound, pattern recognition receptors (PRRs) from the following option are Toll-like receptors(TLR).

TLRs are the membrane-bound Pattern recognition receptors (PRRs). When pathogens breach the skin barrier, they encounter macrophages and other phagocytic cells equipped with specialized "microbial sensors." These sensors include TLRs, NOD-like receptors (NLRs), RIG-I-like helicases, and MDA-5. Among these, TLRs are a crucial part of the innate immune response. They are evolutionarily conserved PRRs that detect pathogen-associated molecular patterns (PAMPs), which are unique to each pathogen and are essential molecular structures required for the pathogens' survival.

The PRRs are either localized on the cell surface to detect extracellular pathogens or within the endosomes and cellular matrix where they detect intracellular invading viruses. They are involved in activating pro-inflammatory signaling pathways, stimulating phagocytic responses (macrophages, neutrophils, and dendritic cells), or binding to micro-organisms as secreted proteins.

Based on the localization and functional characteristics, PRRs are classified as

    • Membrane-bound PRRs
      • TLR
      • C-type lectin receptors (CLR)
    • Cytoplasmic (intracellular) PRRs
      • Nucleotide oligomerization (NOD) like receptors (NLR) – these include NODs (NOD1 and NOD2).
      • Retinoic acid-inducible gene I (RIG-I) like receptors (RLR)
    • Secreted PRRs

Peptidoglycan recognition proteins (PGRPs) are a group of proteins that play a crucial role in the innate immune system by recognizing and binding to peptidoglycan, a major component of bacterial cell walls. Their levels often increase in response to bacterial presence, mediating immune responses.

questions.text: A drug company is developing a new pregnancy test kit for use on an outpatient basis. The company used the pregnancy test on 100 women who are known to be pregnant out of which 99 showed positive. Out of 100 non-pregnant women on whom this test was tried, 90 showed negative result. What is the sensitivity of this test?
questions.solution:
• The sensitivity of the test here is 99%. 
  • The table built here is: 

 

  Pregnant +  Pregnant - 
Test +  99  10 
Test -  1  90 
  • Sensitivity = a/(a+c) x 100 = 99 x 100/100 = 99%.

Related Pearl: Validity of a Screening Test

  • Validity/ accuracy of a screening test depends upon the sensitivity, specificity, and predictive accuracy of the test.
  • It represents the closeness to a true value/ actual value.
  • These are the inherent properties of a screening test.
  • PPV and NPV are dependent on the Prevalence of disease.
  • Sensitivity & Specificity are independent of prevalence of disease.
Formulae 
Sensitivity      TP    
TP + FN
Specificity      TN    
FP + TN
Predictive value of a positive test (PPV)      TP    
TP + FP
Predictive value of a negative test (NPV)      TN     
TN + FN
Percentage of false positives      FP     
FP + TN
Percentage of false negatives      FN     
TP + FN
  • PPV varies directly with prevalence
  • NPV varies inversely with prevalence

questions.text: Which of the following is a genodermal disease that can cause skin malignancies due to defective DNA repair?
questions.solution:
Xeroderma pigmentosa is an autosomal recessive genodermal disease that occurs due to defective DNA repair as a result of defective nucleotide excision and repair pathway.

It is characterized by severe photosensitivity, UV-induced skin and mucous membrane cancers, and neurodegeneration.

questions.text: Having an erotic response to being urinated on is termed as _________:
questions.solution:
• Undinism or urophilia is sexual arousal attained from being urinated on.
  • Troilism is the sexual arousal attained from watching one’s partner having sexual relations with another person.
  • Stigmatophilia is the sexual attraction towards piercing and tattoos.
  • Piquerism is the sexual arousal by piercing and stabbing another person.

questions.text: Which of the following is a direct renin inhibitor?
questions.solution:
• Aliskiren is the direct renin inhibitor approved for the management of hypertension. It is a competitive inhibitor of renin. It binds to active site of renin and inhibits conversion of angiotensinogen to angiotensin.
  • Aprepitant is a NK1 receptor antagonist which is an antiemetic (Option A).
  • Cefditoren is a third generation oral cephalosporin (Option C).
  • Irbesartan is an angiotensin receptor antagonist (Option D).

questions.text: A 45-year-old man is diagnosed with type 2 diabetes mellitus for the first time. When should he visit an ophthalmologist?

choices.text: When symptoms of loss of vision begin to appear

questions.solution:
A patient with type II diabetes mellitus should visit the ophthalmologist at the time of diagnosis of diabetes. 

American Diabetes Association recommends: 

  • For type 2 diabetes mellitus - immediate comprehensive eye examination just after the diagnosis of diabetes 
  • For type 1 diabetes mellitus - comprehensive eye examination within 5 years of diabetes onset.
  • For women with preexisting type 1 or type 2 diabetes who become pregnant or are planning pregnancy - comprehensive eye examination before pregnancy or in the first trimester. Furthermore, these patients should be monitored every trimester and for 1 year postpartum.

After the initial examination in both type 1 and type 2 DM,

  • Annual examination of fundus is recommended therafter.
  • If there is no significant abnormality, the fundus should be examined every 2 years.
Severe vision loss is a microvascular complication of DM primarily due to progressive diabetic retinopathy, characterised by macular edema and new blood vessel formation. Diabetic retinopathy is classified into two stages:
  • Nonproliferative diabetic retinopathy : Usually presents in the 1st decade of hyperglycemia
  • Proliferative diabetic retinopathy

The most effective therapy for diabetic retinopathy is prevention. Hence, intensive glycemic and blood pressure control and routine screening becomes essential. 

Related Pearl: Early treatment diabetic retinopathy study (ETDRS) classification

Non-proliferative diabetic retinopathy (NPDR):

  • Mild NPDR
    • At least one microaneurysm must be present
  • Moderate NPDR
    • Microaneurysms/intraretinal hemorrhage in 2 or 3 quadrants
    • Early mild intraretinal microvascular abnormalities (IRMA)
    • Hard exudates and cotton-wool spots may or may not be present
  • Severe NPDR - any one of the following (4-2-1 rule)
    • 4 quadrants of microaneurysms and extensive intraretinal hemorrhages
    • 2 quadrants of venous beading
    • 1 quadrant of IRMA changes
  • Very severe NPDR - any two of the following (4-2-1)
    • 4 quadrants of microaneurysms and extensive intraretinal hemorrhages
    • 2 quadrants of venous beading
    • 1 quadrant of IRMA changes

Proliferative diabetic retinopathy (PDR):

  • PDR without high-risk characteristics (Early PDR)
    • Early neovascularization at the optic disc (NVD) or neovascularization elsewhere (NVE)
  • PDR with high-risk characteristics as follows
    • NVD < 1/4 disc area with vitreous hemorrhage (VH) or preretinal hemorrhage (PRH)
    • NVD 1/4 to 1/3 of disc area with or without VH or PRH
    • NVE > 1/2 disc area with VH or PRH

Clinically significant macular edema: 1 of the following 3 criteria are present on slit-lamp examination with 90D lens

  • Thickening of the retina at or within 500 micron of the center of the fovea.
  • Hard exudates at or within 500 micron of the centre of fovea associated with adjacent retinal thickening.
  • Development of a zone of retinal thickening one disc diameter or larger in size. At least a part of this should be within one disc diameter of the foveal center.

Advanced diabetic eye disease:

  • Persistent vitreous hemorrhage
  • Tractional retinal detachment
  • Neovascular glaucoma

questions.text: A young female patient has repeated attacks of migraine that requires prophylactic therapy. Which of the following prophylactic agent would you prefer in this patient?
questions.solution:
• Among the above options, topiramate seems the most appropriate for the patient.
  • Sumatriptan and rizatriptan are indicated only in acute migraines (Options C and D).
  • Valproic acid is also indicated in prophylaxis of migraine. Valproic acid has adverse effects like hair loss, weight gain and polycystic ovarian disease that are not desirable in a young female patient.
  • Therefore, topiramate would be the preferred choice.

questions.text: Schizophrenia is characterized by all of the following except
questions.solution:
Elation is not a symptom of schizophrenia.

Symptoms of schizophrenia can be classified as positive or negative.

  • Positive symptoms are things additional to expected behavior and include delusions, hallucinations, agitation, and talkativeness.
  • Positive symptoms respond well to most traditional and atypical antipsychotic agents.
  • Negative symptoms are things missing from expected behavior and include lack of motivation, social withdrawal, flattened affect, cognitive disturbances, poor grooming, and poor (i.e., impoverished) speech content.
  • Negative symptoms respond better to atypical than to traditional antipsychotics.

questions.text: Which of the following is the remnant of umbilical artery?
questions.solution:
The umbilical artery begins to undergo obliteration soon after birth, to form the following structures:

  • Medial umbilical ligament: This is the distal part of the umbilical artery that thromboses soon after birth and hence becomes obliterated; it may be found as a remnant seen in the internal aspect of the anterior abdominal wall.
  • Superior vesical artery: the persistent proximal portion of the umbilical artery; runs along the side wall of the pelvis to its supply at the superior bladder as well as adjacent ureter and ductus deferens.

questions.text: All of the following are true about autoimmune gastritis except:

choices.text: Auto-antibodies to parietal cells and intrinsic factor

questions.solution:
• Autoimmune gastritis is associated with hypergastrinemia.
  • Autoimmune gastritis is characterized by:
    • Antibodies to parietal cells which are responsible for the secretion of gastric acid and intrinsic factor.
    • Reduced serum pepsinogen I concentration.
    • Endocrine cell hyperplasia.
    • Vitamin B12 deficiency.
    • Defective gastric acid secretion (achlorhydria).

questions.text: Which of the following is not indicated for clinical use?
questions.solution:
• Sarin is an extremely toxic anticholinesterase agent and is considered as a nerve gas. It is potentially lethal in nanogram doses to laboratory animals and is used in chemical warfare.
  • Nerve gases are sarin, taubn and soman.
  • Acetylcholine is rarely used systemically but used topically as a rapid miotic agent for ophthalmic surgeries (option A).
  • Bethanechol is a muscarinic agonist and is indicated in non-obstructive urinary retention (Option B).

questions.text: Saturnine gout is seen predominantly in:
questions.solution:
• Saturnine gout is seen in chronic lead intoxication or poisoning.
  • It is associated with chronic renal damage, renal failure and interstitial fibrosis.
  • The features of saturnine gout are the same as primary gout but it affects the knee more than the first metatarsophalangeal joint and tophi rarely develop.

questions.text: A 23 year old female patient presented with diarrhea since 3 days. On examination there were pigmentary changes in skin, hair loss and nail atrophy. On further investigation she was found to have polyps in stomach. Probable diagnosis is ________:
questions.solution:
Combination of gastrointestinal polyposis in association with alopecia, cutaneous pigmentation, and atrophy of the fingernails and toenails suggest diagnosis of Cronkite-Canada syndrome.

  • It is an acquired disorder.
  • Diarrhea is a prominent symptom, and vomiting, malabsorption and protein-losing enteropathy may occur.
  • Polyps are found throughout GIT, most commonly in stomach with characteristic esophageal sparing.
  • Supportive care and steroids for disease recurrence is recommended.

questions.text: Bezold’s abscess is located in:
questions.solution:
Bezold abscess is located in sternomastoid muscle.

It is a complication of acute mastoiditis and an extracranial complication of mastoiditis and active chronic otitis media (COM).

It is a neck abscess in the sternomastoid muscle as a result of direct extension from suppuration in the mastoid tip.

questions.text: You observe the following breathing circuit being used to ventilate a brain-dead patient who is being shifted to the OT for organ procurement. Which type of Mapleson circuit does this belong to?
questions.solution:
The given circuit is the Bain's circuit which is a coaxial modification of the Mapleson D circuit.

Co-axial circuits have two tubings, one inner and one outer tubing (arranged co-axially).

Bain's circuit has

  • Inner inspiratory tubing: carries fresh gas flow to the patient
  • Outer expiratory tubing: carries exhaled gases out through APL (adjustable pressure limiting) valve

Bain's circuit is often called a universal circuit as it can be used for adult and pediatric patients, for spontaneous and controlled ventilation.

questions.text: In Maslow’s hierarchy of needs, which of the following is at the top of the pyramid?
questions.solution:
• Maslow’s hierarchy of needs was suggested by psychologist Abraham Maslow in which human needs are arranged according to hierarchy in a five level pyramid.
  • He suggested that the higher needs can be fulfilled only once the lower needs are fulfilled

Related Pearl: Maslow's Hierarchy of Needs

questions.text: The image of a stillborn foetus is as seen below. All are true about this condition except:

choices.text: Four times more common in girls than boys
Approximately 75% of these tumors are malignant
Develop embryologically from multipotent cells in Hensen’s node

questions.solution:
The image is of Sacrococcygeal teratoma.

Approximately 75% of these tumors are mature teratomas (benign), and about 12% are unequivocally malignant and lethal. The remainder is immature teratomas.

  • Sacrococcygeal teratoma (SCT) is the most common tumor of the newborn with an incidence of 1 in 35,000 to 40,000 live births.
  • In the newborn, the sacrococcygeal site is located at the base of the tailbone (coccyx) and it is the most common location of teratomas in newborns.
  • Neonates have a 2-5% risk of malignancy that increases to 50% at one year and nearly 100% after 5 years of age.
  • It is 4 times as common in girls than boys.

questions.text: A young lady with tremors and diarrhoea and elevated T4 and TSH levels of 8.5 mIU/L. Further examination reveals bitemporal hemianopia. Next step of management is:

choices.text: Start anti-thyroid drugs and do urgent MRI brain
Start anti thyroid drugs and wait for symptoms to resolve

questions.solution:
• The given clinical scenario suggests a diagnosis of TSH-secreting pituitary adenoma.
  • The next step of management would be to start anti-thyroid drugs/ radiotherapy to control thyrotoxicosis.
  • This is followed by a combination of trans-sphenoidal surgery, sella irradiation to normalize TSH.
  • The investigations required for the above procedures would include MRI brain.

questions.text: Which of the following is true about the left renal vein?

choices.text: Posterior and inferior to superior mesenteric artery
Posterior and superior to superior mesenteric artery
Anterior and inferior to superior mesenteric artery
Anterior and superior to superior mesenteric artery

questions.solution:
• The left renal vein is anterior to aorta and posterior and inferior to the superior mesenteric artery.
  • The compression of the left renal vein between the abdominal aorta and the superior mesenteric artery, appears in the saggital plane, as if a nutcracker is crushing a nut (left renal vein).
  • This condition is called nutcracker (left renal vein entrapment) syndrome.
  • It is characterized by left renal vein hypertension secondary to compression, and has been associated with haematuria and varicocele in children.

questions.text: Which of the following is a membrane protein?
questions.solution:
• One of the major classes of glycoproteins is the membrane bound proteins that are anchored to the lipid bilayer by a glycophos-phatidylinsitol (GPI) tail. GPI linkage is the commonest way in which various proteins are anchored to the cell membranes.
  • Option B- Tartrate-resistant acid phosphatase (TRAP or TRAPase) is a glycosylated monomeric metalloprotein enzyme expressed in mammals.
  • Option C- Sec A protein is a part of the Sec machinery (or translocase), which provides a major pathway of protein translocation from the cytosol across the cytoplasmic membrane in bacteria.

questions.text: What is the biochemical basis behind exacerbation of symptoms in a patient with porphyria when there is consumption of barbiturates?
questions.solution:
The biochemical basis behind exacerbation of porphyria by barbiturates is the derepression of ALA synthase(ALAS- 1).

Drugs like barbiturates and griseofulvin are metabolized by microsomal CYP450, a heme-protein oxidase system found in the liver. They increase the synthesis of CYP450, which in turn increases the consumption of heme. This decrease in heme concentration in the liver leads to the de-repression or induction of the enzyme ALA synthase, which is the rate-limiting enzyme for heme synthesis. This leads to increased synthesis of heme precursors which exacerbates the attacks of porphyria.

Related Pearl: Types of porphyria

Clinically porphyrias can be classified into:

  • Hepatic porphyria: The overproduction of heme pathway intermediates occurs primarily in the liver.
  • Erythropoietic porphyria: The overproduction of heme pathway intermediates occurs primarily in bone marrow erythroid cells.

questions.text: All of the following indices are used to determine race of the individual except
questions.solution:
Cephalic index, brachial index, and intermembral index are all used to determine race of the individual except the medullary index.

Medullary index is of two types - 

  • Medullary index of bones:
    • It is used for sex determination. Long bones such as tibia, humerus, radius and ulna are used.
    • Medullary index = diameter of medulla ÷ diameter of whole bone ×100.
  • Medullary index of hair: It is used to differentiate animals and humans. It is the ratio of diameter of medulla and the diameter of the whole hair shaft.
    • Humans: < 0.3
    • Animals: > 0.5

Osteometric indices to determine race are: 

  • Cephalic index  
  • Brachial index 
  • Crural index 
  • Humero-femoral index 
  • Intermembral index

 

Cephalic Index is used to determine the race of the individual, also in determining the age of fetus in lega; and obstetrical cases.

Cephalic index = Maximum skull breadth x 100 / Maximum skull length. Using calipers breadth and length are measured between both parietal eminences and between glabella and external occipital protuberance respectively. 

There are three main racial groups: caucasian, mongoloid, and negroid. 

The skull offers the best evidence of racial origins.

Type of skull Cephalic index Race(s)
Dolichocephalic 70-75 Pure Aryans, Aborigines, Negroes
Mesaticephalic 75-80 Europeans, Chinese, Indians
Brachycephalic 80-85 Mongolian

The skull of an Indian is said to be Caucasian with a few negroid features. 

Related Pearl: Indices for determination of race and sex of an individual

To determine the sex of an individual -

Krogman's degree of accuracy in sexing adult skeletal remains:

  • Entire skeleton – 100%
  • Pelvis alone – 95%
  • Skull alone – 90%
  • Pelvis plus skull – 98%
  • Long bones alone – 80%

questions.solution:
• Myositis specific antibodies are anti-Jo-1 antibodies.
  • Anti-Scl-70 is seen in diffuse systemic scleroderma.
  • Anti-Ro antibodies are associated with Sjogren syndrome and SLE.

questions.text: Which of the following disinfectants features a biguanide functional group?
questions.solution:
• Disinfectants like chlorhexidine and alexidine have a biguanide functional group. They are mostly used as oral disinfectants and hand products. They are bactericidal but not sporicidal. Mycobacteria are also resistant to these compounds.
  • Povidone-iodine is an iodophor, which are halogen-releasing compounds. They are bactericidal in normal concentrations but they adopt sporicidal activity in higher concentrations.
  • Benzalkonium chloride and cetrimide are quaternary ammonium compounds (QACs). Most QACs are not sporicidal

questions.text: All are correct statements about the use of beta blockers in heart failure except:

choices.text: They are not indicated in acute decompensated heart failure
Special precautions should be taken in cases of NYHA class III and IV
They should be started with optimum dose
Carvedilol and metoprolol are the preferred drugs

questions.solution:
• Beta blockers should be started at very low doses because of the risk of acutely worsening the cardiac function. The doses have to be optimized based on individual patient response.
  • Because of the risk of acutely worsening cardiac function, they are not indicated in acute decompensated cardiac failure and used with caution in chronic cases with NYHA class III and IV heart failure (Options A and B).
  • Carvedilol, metoprolol and bisoprolol have shown mortality benefits in large trials and are commonly used in this condition (Option D).

questions.text: A patient presents with ptosis, miosis, anhidrosis and enophthalmos. On examination, the ciliospinal reflex is found to be absent. The treatment of choice for correction of ptosis in the above patient would be:
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario suggests a diagnosis of Horner’s syndrome. Fasanella servat is the treatment of choice for mild ptosis caused by Horner’s syndrome.

Fasanella servat operation is done for cases of mild ptosis (1.5-2 mm) with retained levator palpabrae superioris muscle function as seen in Horner’s syndrome.

Ptosis in Horner's syndrome is due to the loss of sympathetic supply to the muller's muscle of the lid and not due to levator muscle palsy. Fasanella servat operation is not done in patients with severe ptosis and poor levator function.

Option A: Levator resection is performed for moderate and severe grades of ptosis but with retained levator function. This operation is contraindicated in patients with poor levator function.

Option B: Frontalis sling also known as brow suspension is done in patients with severe ptosis with poor or absent levator muscle function. Here, the lid is anchored to the frontalis muscle via a sling.

questions.text: What was the primary goal of the Human Genome Project?

choices.text: To introduce a gene sequence into a cell
To develop new diagnostic techniques for genetic disorders
To determine the sequence of nucleotide base pairs in human DNA
To study the precise genetic composition of specific populations

questions.solution:
The primary goal of the Human Genome Project was to determine the sequence of nucleotide base pairs that make up human DNA and to map all genes from the human genome (20,500 genes).

The project was launched in 1990 and deemed complete in 2003.

questions.text: Meniere’s disease is characterized by all the following except:
questions.solution:
Clinical features of Meniere’s disease include spontaneous vertigo, tinnitus, aural fullness and nystagmus.

Postural imbalance and nausea are common and can last for days after an attack of vertigo.

questions.text: An 8-year-old  child is brought with complaints of pain in the neck and right shoulder with a restricted range of motion. He also experiences difficulty walking. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The clinical history of a child with pain in the neck and right shoulder with a restricted range of motion and difficulty in walking with the clinical image showing winging of the right scapula suggests a diagnosis of facioscapulohumeral dystrophy. 

Facioscapulohumeral dystrophy is an autosomal dominant disorder with weakness of facial and shoulder girdle muscles as the earliest and most severe manifestation. Facial weakness causes rounded and puckered lips and the inability to close eyes while sleeping. Scapular winging is a prominent feature even in infants. There is flattening of the deltoid contour and wasting of the triceps and biceps. There is gradual weakness of muscles of the hip girdle and thighs, which eventually undergo atrophy, leading to Gower's sign and Trendelenburg gait. Lumbar lordosis and kyphoscoliosis are common complications.

Other options:

Option B- Long thoracic nerve palsy can cause scapular winging, most- commonly medial winging, due to traumatic injuries and nontraumatic events due to dysfunction of the serratus anterior.

Option C- Klippel Feil syndrome consists of a triad of low posterior hairline, short neck and decreased cervical range of motion.

Option D-Subacute combined degeneration (SACD) is due to the deficiency of vitamin B12. Pernicious anemia, partial gastrectomy, and Diphyllobothrium latum infestation can lead to this condition. The most severely affected regions in SACD are the posterior columns at the cervical and upper thoracic levels as well as the lateral corticospinal tracts and the cerebral cortex.

questions.text: A 27-year-old primigravida woman at 34 weeks of gestation is reported to have an amniotic fluid index of 4 cm. Which of the following fetal anomaly can be associated with this condition?
questions.solution:
An amniotic fluid index(AFI) of 4 cm is suggestive of oligohydramnios which can be associated with renal agenesis.

Oligohydramnios is a condition where there is decreased production of amniotic fluid. Sonographically, it is defined when the single deepest pocket of liquor is <2 cm or when the amniotic fluid index (AFI) is less than 5 cm (less than 5 percentile).

The fetus begins producing urine between 8 - 11 weeks of gestation. However, it does not become a major part of the composition of amniotic fluid until the second trimester. For this reason, fetuses with kidney abnormalities do not become evident until after 18 weeks of gestation. 

Causes of Oligohydraminios:

  • Placental abnormalities: Amnion nodosum (failure of secretion by the cells of the amnion covering the placenta)
  • Maternal complications leading to uteroplacental insufficiency: pre-eclampsia, vascular disease
  • Renal Anomalies:
    • Bilateral renal agenesis
    • Bilateral multicystic dysplastic kidney
    • Unilateral renal agenesis with contralateral multicystic dysplastic kidney
    • The infantile form of autosomal recessive polycystic kidney dis­ease
    • Fetal bladder outlet obstruction - posterior urethral valves, urethral atresia, or stenosis
  • Complex fetal anomalies: persistent cloaca and sireno­melia (mermaid syndrome).
  • Post-dated pregnancy
  • Drugs: ACE inhibitors, ARBs, NSAIDs when taken in the 2nd or 3rd trimester

Consequently, polyhydramnios is defined as a deepest vertical pocket of more than 8 cm or an AFI of more than 24 cm. There are various mechanisms that can lead to polyhydramnios such as: 

  • Maternal causes
    • Diabetes(Overt diabetes/Gestational diabetes)
    • Cardiac diseases
    • Renal Diseases
  • Fetal causes
    • Neural tube defects
    • Anencephaly
    • Cleft lip/palate, micrognathia
    • Congenital diaphragmatic hernia
    • Esophageal and duodenal atresia
    • Aneuploidy
    • Hydrops fetalis due to Rh alloimmunization, nonimmune hydrops, cardiothoracic anomalies, fetal cirrhosis and fetal TORCH infections, parvovirus B19 infection
    • Twin pregnancy, Twin to Twin transfusion syndrome
    • Bartter syndrome
    • Sacrococcygeal teratoma
    • High-output cardiac states
  • Placental causes
    • Chorangioma of placenta

  • Aneuploidy
  • Hydrops fetalis
  • TTTS

Placental

Failure of secretion:- e.g. Amnion nodosum

Chorangioma of placenta

questions.text: SERM that is approved for use in dyspareunia in menopausal women is ______
questions.solution:
• Ospemifene is a SERM that is approved for use in dyspareunia in menopausal women.
  • Ospemifene has estrogenic agonist actions at vaginal epithelium that causes an increase in vaginal thickness and decreases the symptoms of dyspareunia.

questions.text: Commonest complication following hemorrhoidectomy is:
questions.solution:
Urinary retention is the most common complication following hemorrhoidectomy - seen in 30% of patients.

The other complications are:

  • Fecal incontinence (2%)
  • Infection (1%)
  • Delayed hemorrhage (1%)
  • Stricture (1%)

questions.text: UK refinement of Hanifin and Rajka criteria is used in the diagnosis of which of the following disorders?
questions.solution:
UK refinement of Hanifin and Rajka criteria is used in the diagnosis of atopic dermatitis.

The original Hanifin and Rajka criteria require that patients have at least 3 of the 4 major criteria and 3 of the 23 minor criteria. Consequently, Williams et al. coordinated a UK working party to attempt to refine the criteria of Hanifin and Rajka into a repeatable and validated set of diagnostic criteria for atopic eczema.

Related Pearl: UK refinement of Hanifin & Rajka’s diagnostic criteria of atopic dermatitis (eczema)

In order to qualify as a case of atopic dermatitis (eczema) with the UK  diagnostic criteria, the child must have an itchy skin condition (or parental report of scratching or rubbing in a child).

Plus three or more of the following:

  • Onset below age of 2 years (not used if child is under 4 years)
  • History of skin crease involvement (including cheeks in children under 10 years)
  • History of a generally dry skin
  • Personal history of other atopic disease (or history of any atopic disease in a first-degree relative in children under 4 years)
  • Visible flexural dermatitis (or dermatitis of cheeks/forehead and outer limbs in children under 4 years)

questions.text: A 13-year-old boy was brought to your clinic by his worried mother. He had been suspended twice from his school for bullying, assaulting his classmates and stealing from them. He would sometimes stay out all night despite his parents telling him not to, and he was recently warned by the local police for vandalism. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A 13-year-old boy with a history of aggression towards people within the past 6 months, destruction of property, and theft for the last couple of years points towards a diagnosis of conduct disorder. If it persists beyond 18 years of age it is referred to as anti-social personality disorder.

Conduct disorder is diagnosed when at least 3 behaviors have been present within the previous 12 months, with at least 1 present in the past 6 months.

Conduct disorder can be classified based on onset as:

  • Childhood-onset type: Individuals show at least one symptom characteristic of conduct disorder before the age of 10 years.
  • Adolescent-onset type: Individuals do not show features of conduct disorder before the age of 10 years.
  • Unspecified onset: Criteria for a diagnosis of conduct disorder are met, but there is not enough information available to determine whether the onset of the first symptom was before or after the age of 10 years.
DSM-5 criteria for Conduct Disorder 
Aggression towards people and animals

Initiating physical fights, bullying, threatening, or intimidating others

Using a weapon to cause serious harm to others

Being physically cruel to people

Being physically cruel to animals

Stealing while confronting a victim

Forcing someone into sexual activity
Destruction of property

Setting fires

Intentionally destroying the property of others
Serious violation of rules

Running away overnight at least twice or once without returning for a lengthy period.

Being truant from school often starting before age 13.

Frequently staying out at night despite parental prohibitions starting before age 13
Deceitfulness or theft

Frequently lying to obtain goods or favors

Breaking into a car or building

Stealing items of nontrivial value without confronting a victim

Oppositional defiant disorder (ODD):

  • A persistent pattern of negativistic, hostile, and defiant attitude/behavior towards adults.
  • Seen in children less than 10 years of age.
  • The symptoms must be present at least 6 months, during which 4 or more of the following have to be present:
    • Argues with others
    • Loses temper
    • Blames others
    • Easily annoyed
    • Refuses and defies to listening to adults
    • Annoys other people quite often

Unlike conduct disorder, children with ODD do not indulge in destructive and physically harmful activities.

Disruptive mood dysregulation disorder: Onset before age 10. Severe, recurrent temper outbursts out of proportion to the situation. Child is constantly angry and irritable between outbreks.

questions.text: In Henoch-Schonlein purpura, which immunoglobulin is deposited around the vessels?
questions.solution: Henoch-Schonlein purpura is an IgA vasculitis.

questions.text: The contrast-enhanced CT abdomen of a 50-year-old woman shows the following finding. Which of the following classifications would you use to assess the severity of this condition?
questions.solution:
The given CT image shows a simple renal cyst. The Bosniak classification system is used for the classification of renal cystic masses based on characteristics seen on contrast-enhanced CT. It is helpful in predicting malignancy risk and formulating a management plan.

Bosniak class Appearance Malignancy Management
 1

Simple cyst : 

Rounded with imperceptible wall

 Not malignant No further workup required
2

Minimally complex: 

  • Size <1 mm with septa, thin calcifications

 

 Not malignant No further workup required
2F

Minimally complex:

  • Size >3 cm
  • Increased number of septa
  • Minimally thickened with nodular/thick calcifications
 5% chance  Ultrasound/CT follow-up every 6 months
3

Indeterminate:

  • Complicated cysts, thickened septa
  • Nodular calcification/solid non-enhancing areas (appears hyperdense on CT)
 55% chance

Partial nephrectomy

Radiofrequency ablation (elderly/poor surgical candidates)
4

Solid mass with a large cystic or necrotic component

Clearly malignant (100%)

 Partial/ total nephrectomy

 

Other options:

Option A: Jackson staging is used in carcinoma penis.

Option C: Durie-Salmon staging is used for multiple myeloma.

Option D: Todani classification is used in cases of choledochal cysts.

questions.text: A 7-year-old child was scheduled for strabismus correction surgery. The induction of anesthesia was uneventful. After conjunctival incision as the surgeon grasps the medial rectus the anesthetist looks at the cardiac monitor. Why do you think he did that?

choices.text: To check the depth of anesthesia
To see if there was an oculocardiac reflex
To ensure there were no ventricular arrhythmias

questions.solution:
The anaesthetist would have looked at the monitor as soon as the medial rectus was grasped, to see if there was an oculocardiac reflex.

The oculocardiac reflex is a trigemino-vagal-reflex (afferent through trigeminal nerve, efferent through vagus nerve). It is most common in pediatric patients undergoing strabismus surgery. It is caused by traction on extraocular muscles or pressure on the eyeball and surrounding structures, particularly the medial rectus muscle.

Mechanism of reflex: Stretch receptors are located in the extraocular muscles. Once activated, the receptors send afferents through short and long ciliary nerves. The ciliary nerves will merge with the ophthalmic division of the trigeminal nerve at the ciliary ganglion. The trigeminal nerve carries impulses to the Gasserian ganglion resulting in increased parasympathetic tone and bradycardia.

The manifestation can range from bradycardia (most common) to sinus arrest and ventricular ectopic to ventricular fibrillation. Administration of antimuscarinic drug glycopyrrolate or atropine reduces the incidence of bradycardia during eye surgery.

Treatment is done by temporary cessation of any surgical manipulation, prevention of hypercapnia or hypoxemia with adequate ventilation, IV glycopyrrolate or IV atropine if bradycardia persists. 

Related Pearl: Oculocardiac Reflex

Traction on the extraocular muscles or pressure on the globe causes bradycardia, atrioventricular block, ventricular ectopy, or asystole.

In particular, it is seen with traction on the medial rectus muscle, but it can occur with stimulation of any of the orbital contents, including the periosteum.

Reflex arc involves-

  • Afferent: Orbital contents to ciliary ganglion to ophthalmic division of the trigeminal nerve to the sensory nucleus of trigeminal
  • Efferent: Vagus nerve to the heart.

Procedures evoking the reflex-

  • Strabismus surgery in the paediatric age (most common) 
  • Cataract extraction
  • Enucleation
  • Retinal detachment repair.

Management-

  • Temporary cessation of surgical stimulation until heart rate increases
  • Adequate ventilation, oxygenation, and depth of anaesthesia
  • IV atropine (10 mcg/kg) if bradycardia persists
  • In recalcitrant episodes, local anaesthetic infiltration of the rectus muscles.

Pretreatment with intravenous atropine or glycopyrrolate can be effective in preventing this condition.

questions.text: A patient with disseminated malignancy receiving palliative care presents at night with history of severe nausea and constipation. A provisional diagnosis of hypercalcemia was made which was confirmed with lab values. The next line of management is:
questions.solution:
• IV fluids followed by furosemide is next line of management.
  • The patient in the given situation is likely to have an acute hypercalcemic crisis.
  • This can lead to systolic arrest of the heart.
  • Protocol to be followed is
    • Normal saline- causes rehydration.
    • Furosemide– Leads to urinary calcium loss after rehydration.
    • Lastly bisphosphonates and intranasal calcitonin.

questions.text: Urine microscopy showed following type of crystals. Diagnosis is ______
questions.solution:
Urine microscopy shows coffin lid shaped crystals which is feature of struvite stones.

Related Pearl: Microscopic Appearance of Various Stones

Xanthine, indinavir, and triamterene stones are radiolucent.

questions.text: All the following syndromes are associated with pheochromocytoma except:
questions.solution:
Beckwith-Wiedmann syndrome is associated with Wilms tumour not pheochromocytoma.

Familial syndomes associated with Pheochromocytoma are : 

1) MEN 2A is also known as Sipple's syndrome. The gain of function mutations in RET proto-oncogene occurs in MEN 2A syndrome.  It is characterized by medullary thyroid carcinoma (MTC), pheochromocytomas, and parathyroid tumors. 

2) MEN 2B is associated with MTC, pheochromocytoma, mucosal neuromas, marfanoid habitus, medullated corneal nerve fibers, and megacolon. Parathyroid tumors are generally not seen here, in contrast to the MEN 2A type.

3) Sturge–Weber syndrome is charaterised by

  • Facial port wine nevus - usually found in the distribution of the ophthalmic division (V1) of the trigeminal nerve
  • Glaucoma
  • Ipsilateral leptomeningeal angiomatosis (LAM) - can lead to seizures, mental retardation or hemiplegia and are seen as intracranial tram-track calcifications on CT
  • Pheochromocytoma is also associated with Sturge-Weber syndrome.

4) Von Hippel-Lindau (VHL) disease is characterised by the development of numerous benign and malignant tumours in different organs. It is associated with mutation in VHL tumour suppressor gene on chromosome 3 (VHL has 3 letters: chromosome 3). Pheochromocytoma/paraganglioma is the associated leison. Other features include :  Renal cell carcinoma, Hemangioblastoma, Pancreatic endocrine neoplasm.

5) Neurofibromatosis 1 (NF-1) is also known as Von Recklinghausen syndrome. NF-1 is the most prevalent type and is caused by loss of function mutation of the NF-1 gene. Pheochormocytoma is the associated leison.

NF1 is clinically diagnosed when any 2 of the following 7 features are present:

  • Six or more café-au-lait macules
  • Axillary or inguinal freckling
  • Two or more iris Lisch nodule
  • Two or more neurofibromas or 1 plexiform neurofibroma.
  • A distinctive osseous lesion such as sphenoid dysplasia
    Optic gliomas
  • A first degree relative with NF-1

questions.text: The PCSK-9 inhibitor used for lowering lipid in the body is __________.
questions.solution:
Alirocumab is a monoclonal antibody that inhibits PCSK9. 

PCSK9 is a serine protease that causes lysosomal degradation of the low-density lipoprotein (LDL) receptors present on the surface of the hepatocytes. Monoclonal antibodies directed against PCSK9 such as alirocumab and evolocumab counter this and cause the persistence of LDL receptors on hepatocytes. This leads to more LDL uptake from the circulation, bringing down the LDL-cholesterol levels in patients with familial hypercholesterolemia.

PCSK9 inhibitors are indicated only as adjunctive therapy in patients with familial hypercholesterolemia or established atherosclerotic cardiovascular disease who have elevated LDL-cholesterol levels despite being on maximum statin therapy.

Other options:

Option A: Natalizumab is a monoclonal antibody against integrin α4 used in multiple sclerosis.

Option B: Efalizumab is an anti–LFA–1 antibody used in psoriasis.

Option D: Adalimumab is an anti-TNF-α Monoclonal Antibody used in inflammatory bowel disease.

questions.text: Bertillon system is used for ______
questions.solution:
• Bertillon system is used for identification of individual.
  • It includes descriptive data, body marks, body measurements and photographs.

questions.text: Blood pressure data of 200 persons were collected. The first quartile BP of data was 94 mmHg and the third quartile was 110 mmHg. How many patients lie between the 3rd and 4th quarters?
questions.solution:
• In a quartile, the data is divided by 3 values into 4 equal parts.
  • Thus each part or quarter will have 25% of the values in the distribution.
  • In this scenario, there will be 50 patients in between the 3rd and 4th quarters.

Related Pearl: Quantiles

Quantiles are elements in a distribution that divide it into equal groups.

  • They are also referred to as fractiles.
  • Quantiles are used for continuous, quantitative data.
  • The median is also considered a quantile as it divides a distribution into two equal parts. The median is also the same as the 50th percentile and second quartile.

Types of quantiles:

  1. Tertiles divide a distribution into 3 equal groups
  2. Quartiles divide it into 4 equal parts or quarters
  3. Quintiles divide a distribution into 5 equal groups
  4. Deciles divide a distribution into 10 equal parts
  5. Vigintiles divide it into 20 equal groups
  6. Centiles:
  • They are also called percentiles and are commonly used, especially for ranking marks in an exam.
  • They divide a distribution into 100 equal parts. Here, the median is the same as the 50th percentile.
  • The formula to arrive at the rank order of a value is R = P/100 x (n + 1), where R is the rank of the desired observation, P is the percentile desired and n is the number of variables in the data.

questions.text: Which of the following is false about the mucocele of the gall bladder?
questions.solution:
The gall bladder is easily palpable in mucocele.

  • Mucocele is due to prolonged obstruction of the cystic duct usually by a large solitary calculus.
  • Obstructed GB lumen is progressively distended by mucus or by a clear transudate produced by mucous epithelial cells.
  • Clinical features:
    • A visible, easily palpable, non-tender gall bladder
    • Frequently remains asymptomatic.
  • Treatment: early cholecystectomy

questions.text: Which of the following is not a diagnostic feature of Tourette’s disorder?

choices.text: Attributable to physiological effects of a substance use
Waxing and waning tics that are present for at least a year after onset
Presence of motor tics and at least one vocal tic

questions.solution:
Attributable to physiological effects of a substance is not a diagnostic criterion for Tourette's disorder.

One of the diagnostic features of Tourette’s disorder is that the disturbance is not a direct physiological effect of any stimulant or substance use. 

Tourette's disorder is the most severe tic disorder that more commonly affects boys. It is also associated with attention-deficit/hyperactivity disorder (ADHD) and obsessive-compulsive disorder (OCD).

According to the diagnostic and statistical manual of mental disorders, fifth edition (DSM-5), the following criteria are used for diagnosis:

  • Multiple motor tics and at least one vocal tic should be present during the illness. It need not be concurrent.
  • The onset of illness is before the age of 18
  • The tics can wax and wane in frequency but should persist for at least a year since the first tic onset
  • The disturbance should not be attributable to the use of substances such as cocaine or medical conditions such as Huntington's disease.

The condition is thought to be a genetic disorder. Initially, the tics involve the face and neck which then progresses downwards. It usually disappears during sleep and is attenuated by relaxation or absorption in an activity. 

Mild cases may not require treatment. In severe cases, behavioral interventions are the first line of treatment. Psychoeducation is recommended for families to understand the natural history of the disease. Antipsychotic agents such as risperidone are used for the treatment of tics. Noradrenergic drugs like clonidine can be used for children with comorbid ADHD.

Related Pearl: Timeline in psychiatry

Lasts 6 to12 months with episodes for 2 or more weeks

Postpartum mood disturbances Onset within 4 weeks of delivery
Brief psychotic disorder Lasts < 1 month, usually stress-related
Schizophreniform disorder Lasts 1-6 months
Schizophrenia Lasts > 6 months
Schizoaffective disorder Lasts > 2 weeks

May last > 6 months in presence of chronic stressor
Bulimia nervosa At least 3 months

questions.text: A 70 year old male presented with an episode of syncope. He also gives history of dizziness during defecation and passing of blood in stools. Fecal occult blood test done 3 months ago as a part of routine screening was negative. No history of weight loss. Likely colonoscopic finding is ________:

choices.text: Dilated mucosal and submucosal veins in colon

questions.solution:
Diagnosis is Heydes’ syndrome which is characterized by presence of submucosal dilated vessels in colon most commonly caecum.

Heyde’s syndrome:

Triad of

  • Aortic stenosis– causes syncope, chest pain when severe
  • Gastrointestinal bleeding from angiodysplasia
  • Acquired coagulopathy– acquired type 2 vWD (secondary to valvular stenosis – returns to normal once valve is replaced).

Dilated mucosal and submucosal veins are seen on colonoscopy.

questions.text: Orotic aciduria is associated with the deficiency of which of the following enzymes of the urea cycle?
questions.solution:
• In deficiency of the enzyme ornithine transcarbamoylase results in an accumulation carbamoyl phosphate that reaches the cytosol where it produces orotic acid as an intermediate of the pyrimidine synthesis pathway, and hence leads to orotic aciduria.
  • In hyperammonemia type 2, there is deficiency of the enzyme ornithine transcarbamoylase.


All urea cycle disorders are autosomal recessive except  hyperammonemia type 2 which is X-linked recessive.

Related Pearl: Urea Cycle and its disorders

questions.text: The trachea and the larynx develop from _______
questions.solution:
• The larynx and trachea develops from the laryngotracheal tube.
  • The respiratory diverticulum also known as laryngotracheal diverticulum develops from the ventral wall of the pharyngeal part of the foregut.
  • The free caudal end of the respiratory diverticulum elongates downwards to enter the thorax, where it bifurcates to form the right and left bronchial buds or lung buds, which further develops to form the bronchi and the lung parenchyma.
  • The part of the diverticulum cranial to the bifurcation is known as laryngotracheal tube, which further develops to form the larynx and trachea.

questions.text: The mean arterial pressure is calculated as _______
questions.solution:
• The mean arterial pressure is the average of the arterial pressures measured millisecond by millisecond over a period of time.
  • It is not equal to the average of systolic and diastolic pressure because the arterial pressure remains nearer to diastolic pressure than to systolic pressure during the greater part of the cardiac cycle.
    • The mean arterial pressure = DBP + 1/3 Pulse pressure
      = DBP + 1/3 (SBP-DBP)
      = (3DBP + SBP – DBP)/3
      = 2/3 DBP + 1/3 SBP
      = (SBP + 2DBP)/3
  • The mean arterial pressure is (SBP + 2DBP)/3.

questions.text: All of the following statements are false except:

choices.text: Muramic acid is absent in the cell wall of  prokaryote
Extra chromosomal DNA is present in Mitochondria in prokaryotes
Multiple linear chromosomes present in prokaryotes

questions.solution:
• 80S ribosome is present in Eukaryotes while 70S ribosome is present in prokaryotes.
  • The distinction between prokaryotes and eukaryotes is considered to be the most important distinction among groups of organisms.
  • Eukaryotic cells contain membrane-bound organelles, such as the nucleus, while prokaryotic cells do not.
  • Differences in cellular structure of prokaryotes and eukaryotes include the presence of mitochondria and chloroplasts, the cell wall and the structure of chromosomal DNA.

questions.text: A 13-year-old boy had a gradually progressive plaque on a buttock for the last 3 years. The plaque was 15cms in diameter, annular in shape, with scarring in the center. The most likely diagnosis is _________
questions.solution:
• The above clinical history of progressive plaque on the buttocks with central scarring is suggestive of lupus vulgaris.
  • Lupus vulgaris is a chronic skin infection which is caused by M. tuberculosis.
  • It is a paucibacillary lesion in a previously sensitized host with good immunity.
  • In India, the most common site is buttocks or trunk.
  • In Europe, the most common lesion is in head and neck.
  • The characteristic lesion is a plaque with an irregular edge with islands of active lupus tissue.
  • On diascopy, apple jelly nodules are seen.

questions.text: While doing sigmoidoscopy, if the rectum is inflated with gas, increased peristalsis is seen in ______.
questions.solution: During sigmoidoscopy, when the rectum is inflated with gas, the distension produces passive tension due to stretching of the wall of the rectum, and additional active tension develops in the smooth muscle of rectum.

questions.text: Which type of membranoproliferative glomerulonephritis is called dense deposit disease?
questions.solution: Type II membranoproliferative glomerulonephritis (MPGN II) is referred to as dense deposit disease.

questions.text: A 45 year old lady presents with a 5cm mass in the breast and 3cm node in the ipsilateral supraclavicular fossa. TNM staging is :
questions.solution:
The TNM staging in this patient is T2N3M0.

  • T2 involves mass 2-5cm in size.
  • N3 indicates ipsilateral infraclavicular/internal mammary and axillary/supraclavicular lymph nodes.
  • M0 indicates absence of distant metastasis.

Prefixes for TNM staging:

  • c: clinical staging (e.g. cT1b)
  • p: pathological (histological) staging

questions.text: Grayhack shunt is established between _______
questions.solution:
Grayhack shunt is established between corpora cavernosa and saphenous vein.

  • Distal shunts should be performed first, because they can be done quickly in the emergency room with a True-Cut needle (Winter shunt). If this fails, an operative distal shunt can be performed (Al-Ghorab).
  • Proximal shunts such as Grayhack (corporal-saphenous vein) or Quackel (proximal cavernosum spongiosum) shunts may be required in refractory cases.

Related Pearl: Surgical shunts for ischaemic priapism

questions.text: A gravida 3 female with H/O 2 previous 2nd trimester abortions presents at 22 weeks of gestation with funneling of cervix and length of cervix 20mm. Most appropriate management would be ________
questions.solution:
• The given case is of cervical incompetence and McDonald stitch is the appropriate management.
  • In cervical incompetence, the retentive power of the cervix (internal os) may be impaired functionally and/or anatomically.
  • Repeated mid-trimester painless cervical dilatation (without apparent cause) and escape of liquor amnii followed by painless expulsion of the products of conception are very much suggestive.
  • Diagnosis in pregnancy
    • Clinical (speculum): Painless cervical shortening and dilatation.
    • Sonography: Short cervix < 25 mm; Funneling of the internal os > 1 cm.
    • Speculum examination: Detection of dilatation of internal os with herniation of the membranes.
  • Management includes two types of operations- Shirodkar and McDonald are in current use during pregnancy each claiming an equal success rate of about 80–90%.
  • In McDonald's stitch, the nonabsorbable suture material is placed as a purse-string suture as high as possible (level of internal os) at the junction of the rugose vaginal epithelium and the smooth vaginal part of the cervix below the level of the bladder. The stitch should be removed at 37th week or earlier if labor pain starts or features of abortion appear.

questions.text: A 25 year old female with history of multiple sexual contacts presented with growth on vulva. The probable diagnosis of given image is ________.
questions.solution:
• The probable diagnosis is condyloma acuminata
  • Condyloma acuminatum refers to an epidermal manifestation attributed to the epidermotropic human papillomavirus (HPV).HPV 6 > HPV 11
  • Human papillomavirus (HPV) is transmitted through contact with infected skin or mucosa. The virus invades the cells of the epidermal basal layer through microabrasions. 
  • Anogenital HPV infection is almost always acquired through sexual contact.  
    Warts are not required for transmission but are highly infectious because of their high viral load.

questions.text: The following is the image of an eyelid affected by a rare tumor of cells related to light touch. What is not true about this condition?

choices.text: It is more common in the upper eyelid
Typical presentation is in older adults

questions.solution:
• Merkel cells are sensory receptors that are related to light touch.
  • The above image is of Merkel cells carcinoma which is a rare, highly malignant tumor that usually affects elderly individuals.
  • This condition occurs more commonly in the upper eyelid.
  • Treatment is by excision and sometimes adjuvant therapy.

questions.text: Food standards in India have to achieve a minimum level of quality under:
questions.solution:
• The Prevention of Food Adulteration Act set up the PFA standards which are used to attain a minimum level of quality in food that is attainable in Indian conditions. This is mandatory for all food products in India.
  • Codex Alimentarius gives international standards for quality of food.
  • Agmark standards and Bureau of Indian Standards go one step above the PFA standards and assure excellence. They are not mandatory but PFA is.

questions.text: Large, bulky, friable and destructive vegetations seen on the cusps of valve and mural endocardium are seen in  _______
questions.solution:
Vegetations of IE - Friable, bulky, potentially destructive lesions containing fibrin, inflammatory cells, and bacteria or other organisms on the cusps of valves and mural endocardium.
