questions.text: Annexin V is a marker of ______
questions.solution:
• Annexin A5 (or annexin V) is a cellular protein in the annexin group.
  • In flow cytometry, annexin V is commonly used to detect apoptotic cells by its ability to bind to phosphatidylserine, a marker of apoptosis when it is on the outer leaflet of the plasma membrane

questions.text: A 40-year-old lady abruptly develops high-grade fever with myalgia and bone pain, 18 hours after penicillin treatment for early latent syphilis. Which of the following statements is incorrect about her condition?

choices.text: Penicillin can be used in future
Fever usually comes down within 8 hours
She must be treated with steroids

questions.solution:
A febrile reaction occurring within 24 hours of penicillin therapy for syphilis is suggestive of Jarisch-Herxheimer's reaction. Corticosteroids are only indicated in pregnant women and patients with neurosyphilis in whom the reaction can be more serious and life‐threatening sequelae.

Jarisch–Herxheimer reaction is self-limiting and is due to lipoprotein release from the dying treponemes, which trigger cytokine release.

The patient presents with flu-like symptoms and exacerbation of skin lesions. Fever rarely lasts more than 8 hours.  Symptoms may be controlled by antipyretics. It is not a contraindication for penicillin use in the future.

Penicillin allergy is a contraindication for further use. JH reactions must be differentiated from penicillin allergy. Allergic reactions can be early or late as follows:

  • Early type- anaphylaxis within 1 hour of the first dose.
  • Late type- rash after several doses of penicillin

questions.text: Pain in early labor is limited to dermatomes ____________:
questions.solution:
• Pain in early labor is due to uterine contractions is limited to the dermatomes of T10-L1.
  • Throughout pregnancy there are irregular involuntary spasmodic uterine contractions which are painless (Braxton Hicks) and have no effect on dilatation of the cervix. The character of the contractions changes with the onset of labor.
  • Pain of uterine contractions is distributed along the cutaneous nerve distribution of T10 to L1.
  • Pain of cervical dilatation and stretching is referred to the back through the sacral plexus.
  • With the onset of labor, the uterine contractions cause pain, probably due to
    • Myometrial hypoxia during contractions (as in angina).
    • Stretching of the peritoneum over the fundus.
    • Stretching of the cervix during dilatation.
    • Stretching of the ligaments surrounding the uterus.
    • Compression of the nerve ganglion.

questions.text: Antidiabetic drug with primary action of increasing urinary glucose excretion is:
questions.solution:
• Canagliflozin is a sodium glucose co-transporter 2 (SGLT 2) inhibitor that acts by increasing urinary clearance of glucose.
  • Sitagliptin is a DPP-IV inhibitor that decreases the breakdown of endogenous incretins (Option A).
  • Exenatide is a GLP-1 receptor agonist that mimics incretin effects (Option B).
  • Acarbose is an alpha glucosidase inhibitor that decreases glucose absorption (Option C).

questions.text: A 30 year old female with familial adenomatosis coli presents with a mass in the anterior abdominal wall. Histo-pathological examination of the specimen is as seen below. The cells show nuclear positivity for beta catenin. The most likely diagnosis is _____:
questions.solution:
• Deep fibromatoses (desmoids tumors) are large, infiltrative masses that frequently recur but do not metastasize.
  • Frequent in the teens to 30s, predominantly in women.
  • Abdominal fibromatosis generally arises in the musculoaponeurotic structures of the anterior abdominal wall but tumors can arise in the limb girdles or the mesentery.
  • Deep fibromatoses contain mutations in the APC or β-catenin genes.
  • Majority of tumors are sporadic, but individuals with familial adenomatous polyposis (Gardner syndrome who have germline
  • APC mutations are predisposed to deep fibromatosis.
  • Fibromatoses are gray-white, firm, poorly demarcated masses
  • Marked infiltration of surrounding muscle, nerve and fat.
  • Histopathology - Bland fibroblasts arranged in broad sweeping fascicles amid dense collagen.

questions.text: Which of the following statement is incorrect with regard to Low Molecular Weight Heparin (LMWH)?

choices.text: Risk of Heparin Induced Thrombocytopenia (HIT) is less when compared to unfractionated heparin
Main mode of elimination is through kidneys
Protamine sulfate has no effect on its anticoagulant activity
LMWH are formed by controlled enzymatic or chemical depolymerisation of unfractionated heparin

questions.solution:
• Protamine sulfate incompletely neutralizes the anticoagulant activity of LMWH.
  • The longer chains of LMWH are only neutralized by protamine resulting in complete reversal of anti-factor IIa activity and partial reversal of anti-factor Xa activity.
  • LMWH are derived from controlled enzymatic or chemical depolymerisation of unfractionated heparin (Option D).
  • Risk of HIT is 5 about fivefold lower than unfractionated heparin (Option A).
  • The main mode of elimination is through kidneys and accumulation occurs in renal failure patients (Option B).

questions.text: Which of the following has a good prognosis in sarcoidosis?
questions.solution:
• Lofgren’s syndrome is an acute presentation of sarcoidosis, consisting of arthritis, erythema nodosum and bilateral hilar adenopathy. It has a good prognosis, with > 90% of patients experiencing disease resolution within 2 years.
  • In contrast, patients with the disfiguring skin condition lupus pernio or cardiac or neurologic involvement have bad prognosis and rarely experience disease remission.

questions.text: Which of the following drugs action matches with the following profile most accurately?
questions.solution:
• Dobutamine was earlier thought to be a selective beta 1 receptor agonist. But its action is more complex than previously understood.
  • Dobutamine has relatively more inotropic effect than chronotropic effect.
  • Dobutamine has least effect on peripheral vascular resistance; it also possesses alpha 1 receptor agonist action that is balanced by beta 2 receptor agonist actions in the periphery.
  • Noradrenaline has least beta 2 activity and also possesses alpha 2 agonist activity (Option A).
  • Isoprenaline is a non-selective beta agonist whereas salbutamol is a beta 2 selective agonist. (Options B and D).

questions.text: The incidence of malaria in an area is 20, 20, 50, 56, 60, 5000, 678, 898, 345, 456. Which of these methods is the best to calculate the average incidence?
questions.solution:
• Median is the preferred measure of central tendency here as there are outliers in this distribution of data.
  • The mean of the values here is 7583/10 = 758.3.
  • By arranging the data in order – 20, 20, 50, 56, 60, 345, 456, 678, 898, 5000 – we get the median as (60 + 345 )/ 2 = 202.5.
  • The mode here is 20.
  • The values of 20 and 5000 are extreme values or outliers, i.e., observed values which are very distant from other observations in the distribution.
  • This indicates the usage of median as the measure of central tendency as it is not sensitive to extreme values unlike the mean

Related Pearl: The Median in Biostatistics

  • The median is the central element in a distribution when all the elements are arranged in order.
  • In a distribution that has an odd number of elements, the median is the middle value.
  • In a distribution that has an even number of elements, the median is the average of the middle values, i.e., the arithmetic mean of the two middle values.
  • The median is not sensitive to extreme values, i.e., outliers and thus it is preferred measure of location for very skewed distributions.
  • The drawback of the median is that it doesn’t respond to the actual values of the elements but only to the number of values above or below it.
  • The median is the same as the 50th centile.
  • It is sometimes symbolized by Mdn.
  • The median can be arrived at in ordinal, interval and ratio data scales.

Related Pearl: Mean, Median, Mode in Different Distribution Shapes

  • The relationship between the mean, median and mode depends upon the distribution.
  • In a unimodal symmetrical distribution like a normal distribution, all the three measures are approximately the same, as shown in Figure (2) in the following image, i.e., mean = median = mode.
  • Figure (3) in the following image shows a positively skewed distribution in which the longer tail is towards the positive direction. In this, the mean will be larger than the median and mode, i.e., mean > median > mode.
  • Figure (1) in the following image shows a negatively skewed distribution in which the longer tail is towards the negative direction. In this, the mean will be smaller than the median, i.e., mean < median < mode.

Unimodal symmetrical distribution

Mean = Median = Mode

Positively (right) skewed distribution

Mean > Median > Mode

Negatively (left) skewed distribution

Mean < Median < Mode
  • As seen in the figures above, in any distribution curve, the mode is generally the highest point. The mean will be pulled up or down based on the values in the distribution. The median will lie between the mode and mean and divide the distribution in two equal halves under the curve.
  • A bimodal distribution will have two high points as shown in the image below.
  • Mathematically, the relationship between mode, median and mean in asymmetrical distributions can be given as:
    Mode = 3 median – 2 mean (or) Mean = ½ (3 median – mode).
  • Outlier is the statistical term used for an observation or value that is very distant from other observations in the distribution.
  • In a distribution with outliers, preferred measure of central tendency is the median.
  • Mode is least affected by outliers but mean is the most affected out of all the measures of location.

questions.text: All of the following are indications for a CT scan in patients with head injury except?
questions.solution:
More than one episode of vomiting is an indication for a CT scan in case of head injury.

Related Pearl: NICE Guidelines for CT in Head Injury

National Institute for Health and Care Excellence (NICE) Guidelines for Computed Tomography (CT) in Head Injury

Indications for CT imaging within 1 hour of the following risk factors being identified:

  • Glasgow Coma Score (GCS) <12 on initial assessment
  • GCS <15 at 2 hours after injury on assessment in an emergency department
  • Focal neurological deficit
  • Suspected open, depressed, or basal skull fracture
  • More than one episode of vomiting
  • Post-traumatic seizure

Indications for CT imaging within 8 hours:

  • Age >65 years
  • Bleeding or clotting disorders
  • Dangerous mechanism of injury (e.g., fall from a height of >1 meter/5 stairs, road traffic accident)
  • Retrograde amnesia >30 minutes

questions.text: Which of the following is a protein synthesis inhibitor and a bactericidal agent?
questions.solution:
• Gentamicin is an aminoglycoside antibiotic. Aminoglycoside antibiotics act by binding to 30s ribosome and inhibiting protein synthesis. Their ability to cause misreading of DNA template and formation of aberrant proteins that gets incorporated into bacterial cell membrane makes them bactericidal agents.
  • Cefepime is a bactericidal agent but it is a bacterial cell wall synthesis inhibitor (Option A).
  • Chloramphenicol and erythromycin are protein synthesis inhibitors but are considered primarily as bacteriostatic (Options B and C).

questions.text: In which inborn error of metabolism is “swimming pool odour” characteristically seen?
questions.solution:
• Swimming pool odour is characteristically seen in Hawkinsinuria.
  • It is an autosomal dominant trait, caused due to certain missense mutations in the gene for 4-HPPD.
  • It is symptomatic only during infancy. Manifestations include severe metabolic acidosis, ketosis, failure to thrive, mild hepatomegaly, and swimming pool odour.
  • Mental development is usually normal.
  • Symptomatic infants, asymptomatic affected children and adults excrete hawkinsin, 4-hydroxyphenylpyruvic acid, and its metabolites.
  • Treatment consists of a low- protein diet during infancy. Breastfeeding is encouraged.
  • A trial with large doses of vitamin C (up to 1,000 mg/24 hr) is also recommended.

Related Pearl: Inborn Errors of Amino Acid Metabolism and Their Associated Urine Odor

questions.text: The best laboratory investigation to establish the diagnosis of CSF rhinorrhea is:
questions.solution:
The single best lab investigation to establish the diagnosis of CSF rhinorrhea is the assay of beta-2 transferrin which is present only in the CSF, perilymph and aqueous humor.

The other lab test is testing for glucose oxidase but it is unreliable and is not in use currently.

Other investigative techniques for diagnosis of CSF rhinorrhea include high resolution CT scan, scopy and fluorescein lumbar puncture.

questions.text: Von Gierke’s disease is due to deficiency of which of the following enzymes?
questions.solution:
• Von Gierke’s disease occurs due to deficiency of enzyme Glucose 6 phosphatase.
  • Glycogen storage disease type I (GSD I) or von Gierke disease, is the most common of the glycogen storage diseases. 
  • Clinical manifestations result, directly or indirectly, from:
    • Inability to maintain an adequate blood glucose level during the post-absorptive hours of each day.
    • Organ changes due to glycogen accumulation.
    • Excessive lactic acid generation.
    • Damage to tissue from hyperuricemia.
    • In GSD bleeding and infection risk from blood cell effects

questions.text: Naltrexone is used for which of the following function in opioid addiction?
questions.solution:
• Naltrexone is an orally active opioid antagonist that is used for prevention of relapse in opioid deaddiction after detoxification.
  • Overdose of opioid is treated with short acting parenteral agent, naloxone (Option D).
  • Opioid antagonists are not used in opioid withdrawal as it can precipitate the condition (Options B and C).

questions.text: Which of the following type of streptococcal pyrogenic exotoxin is chromosomally mediated?
questions.solution:
• There are 3 types of streptococcal pyrogenic exotoxins- type A, B and C of which type A and C are phage mediated while Type B is chromosomally mediated.
  • Toxins that are coded by phage DNA include (mneomonic : ABCDE)
    • A and C of streptococcal pyrogenic exotoxin
    • Botulinum toxin C and D
    • Cholera toxin
    • Diphtheria toxin
    • E.coli(EHEC): Verocytotoxin (Shiga-like toxin)

questions.text: Limitation of adduction is seen in:
questions.solution:
• Limitation of adduction is seen in Duane’s retraction syndrome Type 2.
  • Duane’s retraction syndrome - Features are:
    • Cause of restrictive squint.
    • Limitation of abduction – Type 1.
    • Limitation of adduction – Type 2.
    • Limitation of both – Type 3.
    • Retraction of globe on attempted adduction.
    • Widening of palpebral fissure on attempted abduction.

questions.text: Salivary gland tumor with a propensity for perineural invasion:
questions.solution:
Adenoid cystic carcinoma has a propensity for perineural invasion and indolent growth pattern.

  • It is the second most common malignant tumor of the parotid gland.
  • The histological types are tubular, cribriform, and solid.
  • The tubular type has the best prognosis and solid has the worst.
  • Treatment is the removal of the gross tumor with radiation therapy for microscopic disease.

Related Pearl: Important points regarding salivary gland tumors

  • Most common neoplasm of the salivary gland: Pleomorphic adenoma
  • Most common malignant tumor of the salivary gland: Mucoepidermoid carcinoma
  • Most common benign tumor of the salivary gland in children: Hemangioma
  • Most common malignant tumor of the salivary gland in children: Mucoepidermoid carcinoma
  • Most common malignant tumor of the minor salivary glands: Adenoid cystic carcinoma
  • Most common gland affected by pleomorphic adenomas: Parotid gland
  • Tumor of the salivary gland with perineural invasion: Adenoid cystic carcinoma
  • Tumor that shows a hot spot in 99mTc scan: Warthin’s tumor

questions.text: Monteleukast is not indicated in
questions.solution:
• Monteleukast is a leukotriene receptor antagonist and is not indicated in the management of acute asthma to terminate attacks.
  • Leukotriene receptor antagonists are not known to produce any significant immediate effects for beneficial effects in acute asthma management.
  • Indications of monteleukast
    • Asthma maintenance and prophylaxis therapy
    • Prophylaxis of exercise induced bronchospasm
    • Allergic/ perennial rhinitis

questions.text: For galactorrhea and amenorrhea syndromes, additional investigation apart from serum prolactin is ________
questions.solution:
• TSH is the additional investigation to be done along with PRL levels.
  • TRH stimulates both TSH and PRL.
  • In hypothyroidism elevated levels of TRH stimulates TSH as well as PRL.
    • This is the cause of galactorrhea and amenorrhea sometimes seen in hypothyroidism.

questions.text: Tangier disease is:
questions.solution:
• Tangier disease is a rare autosomal recessive  disease that can present as one of the following:
    • Asymmetric multiple neuropathies
    • A slowly progressive symmetric polyneuropathy
    • A pseudo-syringomyelia pattern with dissociated sensory loss
  • In this condition, the tonsils may appear yellowish-orange and there may be a splenomegaly with lymphadenopathy.
  • It is caused by mutations in the ATP-binding cassette transporter 1 (ABC1) gene. This leads to reduced levels of HDL and increased levels of triacylglycerol levels.
  • There is no specific treatment.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a device used to image gamma radiation in scintigraphy?
questions.solution:
A photon camera is not used in scintigraphy.

A gamma camera, also called a scintillation or Anger camera, is used to image gamma radiation-emitting radioisotopes. This technique is known as scintigraphy.

The applications of scintigraphy include:

  • Early drug development. 
  • Nuclear medical imaging to view and analyze images of the human body. 
  • Assess the distribution of medically injected, inhaled, or ingested radionuclides emitting gamma rays.

questions.text: The RDW measures _______

choices.text: The average concentration of hemoglobin in each red cell
The total number of red cells
The percentage of blood volume that is composed of red cells
The variation in red cell size

questions.solution:
• Red blood cell distribution width (RDW or RDW-CV or RCDW and RDW-SD) is a measure of the range of variation of red blood cell (RBC) volume that is reported as part of a standard complete blood count.
  • Normal RDW - Anemia in the presence of a normal RDW may suggest thalassemia.
  • Recent Hemorrhage: typical presentation is high RDW with normal MCV
  • High RDW
    • Iron Deficiency Anemia: Usually presents with high RDW with low MCV
    • Folate and vitamin B12 deficiency anemia: Usually presents with high RDW and high MCV
    • Mixed Deficiency (Iron + B12 or folate) anemia: Usually presents with high RDW and variable MCV.

questions.text: Methemoglobinemia is seen with the following local anesthetic _____
questions.solution:
• Prilocaine causes methemoglobinemia due to the metabolism of the aromatic ring to o-toluidine.
  • Methemoglobinemia is dose dependent and can be treated by intravenous methylene blue.
  • Though prilocaine causes less vasodilation and can be used without a vasoconstrictor, the use is largely restricted to dental anesthesia because of methemoglobinemia.

questions.text: Which of the following is not an HRCT finding of usual interstitial pneumonia?

choices.text: Honeycombing and loss of lung architecture

questions.solution:
• UIP / Idiopathic pulmonary fibrosis:
    • Characteristic findings on HRCT:
      • B/L bibasilar subpleural reticular opacities
      • Honeycombing and loss of lung architecture
      • Traction bronchiectasis
  • Non specific interstitial pneumonia:
    • Characteristic finding on HRCT is B/L subpleural ground glass opacities

questions.text: Le-Veen shunt in ascites is done between peritoneum and _______
questions.solution:
• The Le-Veen shunt is a peritoneovenous shunt between peritoneum and superior venacava.
  • It is done for the relief of ascites due to chronic liver disease.
  • One end of the silastic tube is inserted into the ascites within the peritoneal cavity and the other end is tunnelled subcutaneously to the neck, where it is inserted under direct vision into the internal jugular vein and fed into the SVC.
  • Owing to a one-way valve within the tubing, peritoneal fluid is drawn from the abdomen and drained to the circulation due to the lower pressure in the SVC in comparison with the abdomen during the respiratory cycle.

questions.text: All of the following are used in the treatment of multidrug-resistant (Rifampicin, INH and Ethambutol resistance) genital tuberculosis except:
questions.solution:
Para-amino salicylic acid is not used in the treatment of MDR TB (Resistant to H, R, and E)

Regimen class Intensive phase Continuation phase
BPaLM regimen for 6 months Bdq, pretomanid, linezolid, moxifloxacin  
9- 11 months Short MDR TB regimen Mfx Km/Am Eto Cfz Z H E for 4-6 months Mfx Cfz Z E for 5 months

This is in accordance with the latest NTEP guidelines.

questions.text: A patient of VSD with CCF develops clubbing with no cyanosis. The diagnosis is:
questions.solution:
VSD is the commonest congenital lesion complicated by infective endocarditis. This patient with CCF and clubbing is exhibiting clinical features correlating to endocarditis

  • Some features of infective endocarditis indicating the involvement of the cardiovascular system include appearance of right or left heart failure (as seen in this patient) or development of a new murmur.
  • Features of immunological response include clubbing (as seen in this patient), myalgia, splenomegaly and microscopic hematuria.
  • Clubbing and splenomegaly tend to appear 3 weeks after the onset of endocarditis.

Other options:

  • Right to left shunt would give rise to Cyanosis (which is absent in this patient).
  • Large left to right shunts can develop CCF as a complication but they will not have clubbing (as seen in this patient).
  • Pulmonary edema is unlikely to cause clubbing.

questions.text: Preiser disease is
questions.solution:
• Preiser disease is the avascular necrosis of scaphoid (osteonecrosis).
  • Its main presentation is wrist pain.
  • Investigations include plain radiographs, CT and MRI.
  • If non-operative methods do not relieve its symptoms, then revascularization techniques must be used.
  • If there is significant collapse of scaphoid and radioscaphoid arthrosis, then scaphoid excision with capitate-lunate-
  • triquetrum-hamate fusion or with proximal row carpectomy can be done.

questions.text: A 65-year-old man has been experiencing worsening headaches and new-onset seizures. MRI with contrast was done and is given below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given MRI finding is suggestive of glioblastoma. Post-contrast MRI in the case of glioblastoma multiforme, demonstrates a large heterogeneous mass that crosses the corpus callosum into both frontal lobes. 

They have a preferential spreading along the condensed white matter tracts such as corticospinal tracts and corpus callosum and can give rise to the so-called butterfly glioma, to involve the contralateral hemisphere. The term butterfly refers to the symmetric wing-like extensions across the midline. 

There is also evidence of a previous left-sided craniotomy and biopsy tract down to the lesion.

Glioblastoma is the second most common adult primary intracranial neoplasm. It carries the worst prognosis (WHO grade IV).

questions.text: Which of the following drugs is least likely to cause strong physical and psychological dependence?
questions.solution:
The physical and psychological dependence potential of MDMA (3,4 methylenedioxy-methamphetamine) is not well established. It is an illegal, synthetic drug classified as a stimulant with potentially hallucinogenic properties. It is a very popular recreational drug with the street name 'ecstasy'.

Agents, known to cause strong physical and psychological dependence:

  • Opioids
  • Alcohol
  • Nicotine
  • Cannabis
  • Barbiturates

Note: Although classically described as nonaddictive, cases of MDMA dependence have been reported.

questions.text: An 18-year-old girl with pustular acne comes to your clinic for follow-up saying that her acne has not reduced even after taking medications for 6 months. Which of the following drugs will you now prescribe?
questions.solution:
Oral isotretinoin, an oral retinoid is indicated for the treatment of recalcitrant acne.

Recalcitrant acne is poorly responsive acne, less than 50% improvement after 6 months of therapy with combined oral and topical antibiotics.

Related Pearl: Global Alliance Algorithm for Acne Treatment

Global Alliance Algorithm for Acne Treatment

Image: Global Alliance Algorithm for Improving Outcomes in acne

BPO - Benzoyl peroxide

questions.text: The aortic hiatus contains _____

choices.text: Left gastric vein and thoracic duct

questions.solution:
• The aortic hiatus / Aortic opening, transmits Aorta, Azygous vein and Thoracic duct.
  • The aortic hiatus is the most postero-inferior of the large openings, and is found at the level of the lower border of the twelfth thoracic vertebra.
  • It is actually an osseo-aponeurotic opening defined by the diaphragmatic crura laterally, the vertebral column posteriorly and the median arcuate ligament anteriorly.
  • The aorta therefore passes posterior to the diaphragmatic musculature and is not affected by its contraction.

questions.text: Most common cause of OPSI-Overwhelming Post Splenectomy Infection is
questions.solution:
The most frequently involved organism in OPSI is S. pneumoniae, which is estimated to be responsible for between 50% and 90% of cases.

Other organisms involved in OPSI include

  • H. influenzae
  • N. meningitidis
  • Streptococcus
  • Salmonella spp., other pneumococcal organisms.
  • Capnocytophaga canimorsus is implicated in OPSI as a result of dog bites.

questions.text: Which of the following is a special stain for melanin?
questions.solution:
Fontana-Masson is a special stain for melanin. Other methods of detection for melanin are Schmorl's method, DOPA oxidase method, bleaching techniques and formalin induced fluorescence.

Other options:

Giemsa- A Romanowsky type 2 stain used for G banding, peripheral smears, H.pylori, mast cells.
Gomori methanamine silver / GMS is used to stain fungi and for Pneumocystis jiroveci (carinii). 
Von Kossa is a special stain for calcium.

 

Image :  Masson Fontana stain of a metastatic deposit of malignant melanoma. The brown pigment stains black after staining

questions.text: A child presents with megaloblastic anemia that is unresponsive to Vit C, B12 and folic acid, but responsive to uridine. What do you suspect?
questions.solution:
Orotic aciduria is a rare disorder in children, resulting from a block in the metabolism of orotic acid.

Other causes of megaloblastic anemia:-

  • Cobalamin deficiency/abnormalities of cobalamin metabolism: Nutritional, Malabsorption, absence of intrinsic factor, total/ partial gastrectomy
  • Folate deficiency/ abnormalities of folate metabolism
  • Therapy with antifolate drugs e.g., methotrexate
  • Independent of cobalamin/folate deficiency: Acute myeloid leukemia, myelodysplasia
  • Therapy with drugs interfering with the synthesis of DNA (e.g., cytosine arabinoside, hydroxyurea, 6-mercaptopurine)
  • Orotic aciduria (responds to uridine)

Administration of uridine, which is converted to UMP, will bypass the metabolic block and provide the body with a source of pyrimidine.

Related Pearl: Morphological Classification of Anemias

 

Microcytic Hypochromic

(MCV <80 fl)

Normocytic Normochromic    

(MCV 80 - 100 fl)

Macrocytic Normochromic

(MCV >100 fl)

Iron deficiency anemia

Sideroblastic anemia

Thalassemia

Lead toxicity

Acute blood loss

Anemia of chronic disease

Anemia of renal disease

Hemolysis*

Bone marrow suppression

  • Aplastic anemia
  • Pure red cell aplasia

 

  

Megaloblastic:

Vitamin B12 deficiency

Folate deficiency

Thiamine deficiency

Drugs - Methotrexate, Zidovudine, hydroxyurea

Orotic aciduria

 

Non-megaloblastic:

Alcohol use

Liver disease

Hypothyroidism

Hemolysis*

 

*Hemolysis can be associated with macrocytosis because of compensatory reticulocytosis. However, MCV can be normal depending on the degree of hemolysis.

Note: In Orotic Aciduria, peripheral blood smear shows Hypochromic megaloblastic anemia.

questions.text: Following is an image of a German film producer and director “Niko von Glasow”. Identify the most appropriate teratogen causing the defect.
questions.solution: The characteristic seal limbs (phocomelia) associated with thalidomide use during pregnancy can be seen in the image.

questions.text: In a patient with full-thickness burns of 40%, which of the following colloid-based formula should be used to transfuse proteins within 12 hours?
questions.solution:
• The most common colloid-based formula is the Muir and Barclay formula:
    • 0.5 × percentage body surface area burnt × weight = one portion;
    • Periods of 4/4/4, 6/6 and 12 hours, respectively;
    • One portion to be given in each period.
  • Parkland formula is used to calculate the crystalloid volume to be given in the first 24 hours.
  • Wallace rule of nine is used to calculate the percentage of burn.

questions.text: A 65-year-old male patient complains of intermittent epigastric pain that is worse with food intake over the past 3 months. On further evaluation, he was found to have peptic ulcer disease caused by H. pylori. Which of the following drugs is not used in H. pylori eradication?
questions.solution:
Mosapride is a gastrokinetic 5-HT4 agonist and is not indicated in H. pylori eradication.

Proton pump inhibitors like omeprazole or H2 receptor antagonists like cimetidine are usually present in anti-H. pylori regimens for reducing the pH of gastric secretions.

Antimicrobials are used in the treatment of H. pylori infections as well. These include

  • Clarithromycin
  • Metronidazole 
  • Tetracycline
  • Amoxicillin 

H.pylori is a gram-negative motile rod with flagella. It has a unique feature of urease production, which is helpful in diagnosis. The sole source of H.pylori is human gastric mucus. In some patients, H.pylori causes mild acute gastritis lasting for about two weeks. In others, it can cause peptic ulcer disease, which may lead to chronic atrophic gastritis in later stages. This is a risk factor for gastric malignancies like adenocarcinoma and mucosa-associated lymphoid tissue (MALT) lymphomas. 

Many regimens generally indicated for eradication of H. pylori infections are given below.

Related Pearl: Chronic granulomatous disease

Chronic granulomatous disease (CGD) is due to the defect in NADPH oxidase. This interferes with the killing of bacteria by oxidative burst. Hence, the patients are at increased risk of infection from catalase-positive bacteria.

 It can be:

  • X linked - Defect in one of the membrane-bound components (gp91phox) or
  • Autosomal recessive - Cytoplasmic components (p47phox and p67phox)

Diagnosis of CGD includes:

  • Nitroblue tetrazolium test - This is the standard for phagocyte oxidase activity measurement. The colorless compound NBT is reduced to blue formazan by the activity of the functional phox enzyme system. Normally, more than 95% of the granulocytes will be positive. The NBT is negative in CGD due to absence of phox enzyme activity.
  • Dihydrorhodamine (DHR) test - The most accurate diagnostic test for CGD. Normally functioning phagocytic cells oxidize DHR to the strongly fluorescent compound rhodamine which is quantified by flow cytometry.

questions.text: A randomized trial comparing the efficacy of two drugs showed a difference between the two with a p value of <0.005. In reality, both drugs do not differ at all. This is an example of:
questions.solution:
• In this scenario, let’s take the null hypothesis as the two drugs being the same, which the questions states, is true in reality.
  • The alternative hypothesis will then be that both drugs are different.
  • The questions states that p value was found to be < 0.005, which is statistically significant and so the null hypothesis is rejected.
  • But we already know that the null hypothesis is true and we are forced to accept the alternative hypothesis even though it is false.
  • This is a type I error or alpha error.
  • When an alternative hypothesis is accepted even when it is false and the null hypothesis is true, it is a type I error or false positive error.

Related Pearl: Concepts in Hypothesis Testing

Probability value (p value)

  • A probability value is the probability of an outcome given the hypothesis.
  • It is not the probability of the hypothesis given the outcome, although the probability of the given hypothesis is not ignored.
  • If the probability of an outcome is sufficiently low, we have evidence that the hypothesis is false.
  • It is also called the p value.

The Null Hypothesis and Alternative Hypothesis

  • The hypothesis that an apparent effect or outcome is only due to chance is a null hypothesis.
  • In other words, a null hypothesis is one where there is no difference between the specified sample and population and any observed difference is due to chance or some other error.
  • A null hypothesis is represented by H0.
  • If the null hypothesis is rejected as false, then there is an alternative or experimental hypothesis (HA), which is logically accepted.

Criterion or Significance Level (α)

  • If the probability value of an outcome is sufficiently low, then the null hypothesis is rejected.
  • This point below which we would define the probability value as being low enough to reject the null hypothesis is called the criterion or significance level or α (alpha) level.
  • When the null hypothesis is rejected, the effect or outcome is said to be statistically significant.
  • By convention (but not always), the level of α is 0.05, i.e., if the probability value of an outcome is less than or equal to 0.05 (p value ≤ 0.05), then the null hypothesis is rejected.
  • If it is greater than 0.05, then the null hypothesis is accepted.
  • Although by convention the level of α is 0.05, it can be lower but cannot be any higher.

Type I Error

  • The interpretation of p value ≤ 0.05 is that an investigator can be 95% sure that the result was not obtained by chance.
  • It also means that there is a 5% probability that the result was obtained by chance.
  • From this, we can deduce that the null hypothesis might indeed be true even though we rejected it.
  • This is a type I error. In other words, when an alternative hypothesis is accepted even when it is false and the null hypothesis is true, it is a type I error or false positive error.
  • It is also called an alpha (α) error as it is related to the criterion α.
  • The lower the α level, the lower the rate of a type I error being made.
  • Thus, it can be said that α is the maximum tolerable probability that a type I error is being made and that the p value is the probability that a significant difference is declared when there is none.

Type II Error

  • The error that is made by rejecting an alternative hypothesis when it is true or failing to reject a null hypothesis when it is false is called a type II error.
  • It is also called a false negative error and more commonly, as a beta (β) error.
  • If the null hypothesis is false, then the probability of a type II error is β.
  • The power of a statistical test is indicated by 1–β.

Power of a Test

  • The power of a test is the ability of a statistical test to avoid a type II error, which depends on its ability to detect a false null hypothesis.
  • It is equal to 1–β, which is the probability that a false null hypothesis will be rejected.
  • By convention, a test is required to have a power of 0.8 (or a β of 0.2) to be acceptable. This is to say that a study that has less than 80% chance of detecting a false null hypothesis is unacceptable.
  • Type I errors are easily reduced by reducing the criterion α.
  • A test's power will increase in the following conditions:
    • If α increases, but this will increase the chance of a type I error.
    • If the difference between the sample mean and hypothesized mean increases. This is also called effect size.
    • If sampling error decreases.
    • If the sample size (n) increases.

questions.text: ‘Demographic processes’ doesn’t include:
questions.solution:
The demographic processes include fertility, mortality, marriage, migration and social mobility.

These processes are continuously at work in a population determining its size, composition and distribution.

questions.text: A patient complains of hoarseness of voice and constant tickling sensation in his throat. The sensation then turned into pain after a couple of weeks. Laryngoscopy showed an arytenoid granuloma. Which of the following statements is false about the condition?

choices.text: It is a hyperkeratotic lesion present within the anterior 2/3rd of the vocal cords
It is not a premalignant lesion

questions.solution:
An arytenoid granuloma is also known as contact ulcer or pachydermia or granuloma, vocal process or intubation or peptic granuloma. They are benign inflammatory lesions that arise from the medial surface of the arytenoid cartilage and vocal processes.

Its etiology includes injury to the mucoperichondrium over the vocal processes by mechanical trauma as from intubation or strenuous coughing etc.

Clinical features include change in voice, tickling sensation and pain on coughing or clearing throat. It can be unilateral or bilateral. It can be anything from a small diffuse mass to a large nodular, pedunculated mass.

Diagnosis is done by microlaryngoscopy and biopsy.

Surgery alone is not enough as a cure as it has a high rate of occurrence. Main treatment includes reduction of laryngeal irritants.

questions.text: All of the following increases the rate of postmortem cooling except

choices.text: Increased difference in the temperature between body and atmosphere
Larger surface area of the body

questions.solution:
Edema decreases the rate of post-mortem cooling.

Factors increasing the rate of postmortem cooling:

  • Increased difference in the temperature between body and the atmosphere 
  • Large body surface area  
  • Children and old aged people 
  • Higher humidity and rapid air velocity 
  • Body immersed in running water  

Rate of cooling is decreased in:

  • Excess fat 
  • Edema 
  • Body covered with clothing 
  • Bodies in small, ill-ventilated room.

questions.text: Which of the following bacteria shows lysogenic conversion, by taking, tox+ phage genome?
questions.solution:
The toxigenicity of diphtheria bacillus depends on the presence in it, the corynephages (tox+), which acts as the genetic determinant controlling the toxin production.

Non toxigenic strains may be rendered toxigenic by infecting them with beta phage or some other phage.

This is known as lysogenic or phage conversion.

The toxigenicity remains only as long as the bacillus is lysogenic.

When the bacillus is cured of its phage, by growing it in the presence of antiphage serum, it loses the toxigenic capacity.

questions.text: Total ATP generated per turn of the TCA cycle(considering one molecule of pyruvate enters it) is
questions.solution:
10 ATP are generated per turn of the TCA cycle

The following steps of the TCA yield ATP:

  • Isocitrate to alpha keto glutarate – Yields 1 NADH per turn
  • Alpha keto glutarate to Succinyl CoA – yields 1 NADH per turn
  • Succinyl Co A to Succinate – yields 1 GTP (Substrate level phosphorylation)
  • Succinate to fumarate – Yields 1 FADH2
  • Malate to Oxaloacetate – Yields 1 NADH

questions.text: Which of the following statements is true?

choices.text: Fluid coming from the descending loop of henle is hypotonic
Descending limb of loop of henle is permeable to solutes
If clearance of a substance is greater than GFR, then tubular secretion must be present
Clearance of a substance is always more than GFR if there is tubular secretion

questions.solution:
• Glomerular filtration rate (GFR) is the amount of plasma ultrafiltrate formed each minute.
  • Renal plasma clearance is the volume of plasma from which a substance is completely removed by the kidney in a given amount of time (usually minutes).
  • If clearance is more than GFR, then tubular secretion must be present.
  • But, tubular secretion does not mean that clearance would be more than GFR always because if reabsorption occurs in a different segment of the nephron after secretion, clearance may be low also.
  • So, Option D is not always correct.

questions.text: The chromatin in a nucleus of a cell, which appears loose and stains lightly with hematoxylin and eosin is known as ________
questions.solution:
The chromatin in a nucleus of a cell, which appears loose and stains lightly with Hematoxylin and eosin is known as Euchromatin.

  • On staining with haematoxylin and eosin, the nucleus stains dark purple or blue while the cytoplasm is usually stained pink.
  • However, in some cells the nuclei are relatively large and light staining.
  • Such larger nuclei appear to be made up of a delicate network of fibres called chromatin (because of its affinity for dyes).
  • At some places (in the nucleus) the chromatin is seen in the form of irregular dark masses which are called heterochromatin. At some other places the network is loose and stains lightly and is referred to as euchromatin.

questions.text: True regarding the excitation contraction coupling in smooth muscle is

choices.text: Sustained contraction occurs with high calcium concentration
Phosphorylation of actin is required for contraction
Presence of cellular calcium is essential to cause muscle contraction

questions.solution:
Muscle contraction will take place only in the presence of cellular calcium.

  • Option A- Troponin is not present in smooth muscles.
  • Option B- Sustained contraction is possible even with fewer amounts of Ca++ and less use of ATP (Latch bridge phenomenon).
  • Option C- Phosphorylation of myosin is required for contraction.

questions.text: Identify the structure present in the internal ear as shown in the histological image below
questions.solution:
The above histological image is that of the cochlea which can be identified by the presence of characteristic organ of corti.

The cochlea consists of a bony canal that makes 2.75 spiral turns around an axis of bone known as the modiolus. A shelf of bone from the modiolus forms a ridge known as the spiral lamina.

The basilar membrane supporting the organ of Corti extends from the spiral lamina to the outer wall of the cochlea. The vestibular membrane runs from the spiral lamina to the outer wall above the basilar membrane. These two membranes divide the bony labyrinth into three cavities:

  • The scala vestibuli, located between the roof of the labyrinth and the vestibular membrane, is lined by mesenchymal cells and contains perilymph.
  • The scala media, located between the vestibular membrane and basilar membrane, contains endolymph.
  • The scala tympani, located between the basilar membrane and the floor of the labyrinth, is lined by mesenchymal cells and contains perilymph.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a feature of Gerstmann syndrome?
questions.solution:
• Features of Gerstmann syndrome include finger agnosia, acalculia, alexia and right-left confusion.
  • It usually results due to lesions in brain, mostly in the parietoccipital cortex of the dominant hemisphere including the angular gyrus.
  • It can occur due to trauma to the brain in adults and can be due to developmental disorders in children.

questions.text: Exclamation mark hair is seen in patients with which of the following disorder?
questions.solution:
Exclamation mark hair is a feature of alopecia areata.

Alopecia areata is a chronic inflammatory disease that causes non-scarring hair loss. It is a T-cell mediated inflammatory disease. It is associated with several autoimmune diseases including thyroiditis, lupus erythematosus, vitiligo, and psoriasis. It mainly affects the scalp, but can also affect the beard, eyebrows, and eyelashes. In some cases, it may progresses to a total loss of scalp hair (alopecia totalis) or a loss of all hair on the body (alopecia universalis).

The lesions of alopecia areata are characterized by a smooth circumscribed patch of alopecia. Some broken hairs can be seen which are narrower at the base and therefore are called exclamation marks. The disease affects pigmented hair and spares white hair. Fine stippled pitting of the nails and roughening of the nail bed, which is called trachyonychia is also seen in this condition.

Histopathology will show perifollicular and intrafollicular T-lymphocyte infiltration.

Spontaneous remission occurs in a majority of the patients. Topical steroids like clobetasol can be useful in patchy alopecia areata. Intralesional steroids are the most effective treatment for patchy alopecia areata. A depot steroid-like triamcinolone administered by fine-needle injection into the upper subcutis can stimulate hair growth at the site. Multiple injections are usually required. Severe and long-standing alopecia areata requires oral corticosteroids.

The image below shows exclamation mark hair.

 

Other options - 

Option A: Telogen effluvium can occur 2-3 months after systemic stress such as surgery or illness, but it causes diffuse hair loss.

The image below shows a patient with telogen effluvium.

 

Option B: Tinea capitis is the ringworm of the scalp. The appearance may vary from dull grey, broken‐off hairs with a little scaling to a severe, painful, inflammatory mass covering the entire scalp. Predominantly seen in children, however, adults can also be affected due to infection by T.tonsurans.

The image below shows tinea capitis.

 

Option D: Trichotillomania is a behavioural disorder characterised by compulsive pulling of hair. It presents as an area of patchy hair loss, often in a bizarre pattern. The hairs are often twisted and broken at various distances from the scalp or may be present as a uniform, coarse stubble. The scalp skin appears normal. Sites other than the scalp can also be affected, for example- eyelashes, eyebrows, beard, mons pubis, and perianal region. Dermoscopy of the scalp helps in differentiating it from alopecia areata - follicular orifices appear as yellow dots in trichotillomania. Scalp biopsy shows intraepithelial and perifollicular haemorrhages. The presence of numerous empty canals is the most consistent feature of this condition.

The image below shows a patient with trichotillomania.

questions.text: The following appearance on USG is seen in _______
questions.solution:
Characteristic sonographic feature of molar pregnancy is “snowstorm” appearance.

Hydatidiform mole is principally a disease of the chorion.

Failure of the embryo to grow is essential to develop complete (classic) hydatidiform mole. The secretion from the hyperplastic cells and transferred substances from the maternal blood accumulate in the stroma of the villi which are devoid of blood vessels. This results in distension of the villi to form small vesicles.

questions.text: May-Thurner syndrome involves?
questions.solution:
May-Thurner syndrome involves left iliac vein compression.

At the site where the right iliac artery crosses over the left iliac vein, the left iliac vein may become chronically narrowed predisposing to iliofemoral venous thrombosis. This is called May-Thurner syndrome.

questions.text: Sternocleidomastoid muscle is supplied by all of the following arteries except:
questions.solution:
Sternocleidomastoid receives its blood supply from the following:

  • Branches of the occipital and posterior auricular arteries (upper part of muscle)
  • The superior thyroid artery (middle part of muscle)
  • The suprascapular artery (lower part of muscle). 

Note: Although the suprascapular artery is a branch of the thyrocervical trunk, in the above question, thyrocervical trunk is the better answer as all other arteries directly supply the sternocleidomastoid muscle.

questions.text: Riocigaut is a soluble guanylate cyclase stimulator indicated for the treatment of
questions.solution:
• Riocigaut is indicated in the treatment of pulmonary arterial hypertension.
  • Soluble guanylate cyclase (sGC) is a receptor for nitric oxide through which cGMP levels are increased.
  • In pulmonary arterial hypertension, the NO-sGC-cGMP pathway is downregulated because of endothelial dysfunction.
  • Riocigaut stimulates sGC directly by binding to it and indirectly by increasing the effect of NO on sGC.

questions.text: Identify the type of suturing technique shown in the image below.
questions.solution:
The suturing technique shown in the image is mattress suture.

Mattress sutures can be vertical or horizontal and are used to create either an eversion or inversion of the wound edges. The initial suture is inserted in the same way as an interrupted suture, but then, the needle either moves horizontally or vertically and traverses both edges of the wound once again, as seen in the figure. The main advantage of the mattress suture is that it produces an accurate approximation of wound edges, especially in settings where the edges are not easily approximated.

In interrupted sutures, the needle should be inserted at right angles to the incision and should exit at a right angle with the skin. The needle should be rotated through the tissue and should not be dragged through to avoid unnecessary enlargement of the needle hole. If 'x' is the depth of the wound, then the distance from the entry point of the suture to the edge of the wound must be 'x'. Distance between 2 consecutive sutures must be '2x'. 

Continuous suture technique: The first suture is inserted in a manner identical to that in an interrupted suture. The remaining sutures are inserted in a continuous manner until the far end of the wound is reached. Care should be taken to maintain the tension of the suture to avoid excessive tension or leaving it too slack; hence, the use of an assistant is warranted. An Aberdeen knot is used to secure the end of the suture.

Subcuticular sutures is used for a better cosmetic appearance. It is also employed in situations where the edges of the wound are easily approximated. In this technique, small bites of the subcuticular tissues are taken on alternate sites of the wound, and then, they are gently pulled together. This causes an approximation of the wound edges without the risk of the cross-hatched markings of interrupted sutures.

questions.text:
A 40 year old male presents with complaints of bleeding gums for the past 2 weeks. He has thickened and friable gums with hepatosplenomegaly with generalized non-tender lymphadenopathy. The blood count reveals: Hb - 10g/dl 
Platelet count 80,000/mm3 
WBC count 4000/mm3 
The peripheral smear is as seen below  
The bone marrow aspiration and biopsy shows many large blasts that are peroxidase negative and non-specific esterase positive. What of the following is the most likely diagnosis for this patient?
questions.solution:
The clinical presentation, morphology and cytochemistry are suggestive of acute monocytic leukemia.

Subtypes

  • 80%+ of monocyte lineage cells are monoblasts – Acute monoblastic leukemia
  • <80% of monocyte lineage cells are monoblasts, usually < 20%) – Acute monocytic leukemia 

Acute monocytic leukemia

  • High incidence of bleeding disorders (including DIC), organomegaly, lymphadenopathy, gingival hyperplasia, CNS and other tissue involvement (monocytes infiltrate)
  • Greater than 20% blasts in the bone marrow, and of these, greater than 80% must be of the monocytic lineage.
  • Monoblasts can be distinguished by having a roughly circular nucleus, delicate lacy chromatin, and abundant, often basophilic cytoplasm.
  • Monoblasts are typically MPO-negative and promonocytes are MPO variable.
  • Both monoblasts and promonocytes stain positive for non-specific esterase(NSE).

questions.text: The following patch on the cornea is associated with infection by ______:
questions.solution:
The above image depicts Salmon patch appearance of cornea.

Salmon patch appearance of cornea is classically associated with syphilitic infection.

It is due to deep vascularization of cornea consisting of radial bundle of brush-like vessels

Stages of interstital keratitis in Congenital syphilis :

  • Initial progressive – Ground glass appearance
  • Florid stage – Salmon patch appearance
  • Stage of Regression – Ghost vessels

questions.text: Following a term Caesarean delivery, a newborn presents with fast breathing. On examination, respiratory rate is 68/min and the chest is clear. A chest X-ray shows fluid in the intralobar fissures and perihilar pulmonary vascular markings. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The most prominent diagnosis in a newborn with tachypnea, clear chest, and given X-ray findings of intralobar fluid and perihilar pulmonary vascular markings is transient tachypnea of the newborn (TTN).

TTN is a self-limited cause of tachypnea associated with delayed absorption of fetal lung fluid. It is characterized by early-onset tachypnea that is relieved by minimal oxygen supplementation (<40%). There maybe retractions, expiratory grunting, or cyanosis which also resolves with oxygen. On examination, the chest is clear without crackles or wheeze.

The chest X-ray shows prominent pulmonary vascular markings, fluid in the intralobar fissures, and, rarely, small pleural effusions.

Most infants recover usually within 3 days with supportive care.

Other options:

Option A: Hyaline membrane disease- Radiographic findings like hypoaeration, diffuse reticulo-granular pattern, and air bronchograms will be seen.

Option B: Meconium aspiration syndrome occurs in term or post-term infants. The infants are meconium-stained and may be depressed and require resuscitation at birth; The typical chest radiograph is characterized by patchy infiltrates, coarse streaking of both lung fields, and hyperinflation.

Option D: Congenital diaphragmatic hernia presents with respiratory distress, scaphoid abdomen, and bowel sounds heard in the chest wall.

questions.text: Sparse axillary hair appears at which stage of axillary hair development?
questions.solution:
Sparse axillary hair appears at stage 2 of axillary hair development

Axillary Hair Development  
The sequence of axillary hair development is as follows:  

  • A1—prepubertal stage. No axillary hair present.  
  • A2—appearance of sparse axillary hair
  • A3—adult distribution of thick, coarse and dark pigmented hair 

Thelarche  

  • The first sign of puberty is the development of the breasts.  
  • Breast budding usually appears between the ages of 9–11 years; it is indicative of the competency of the hypothalamic– pituitary–ovarian axis. 

Stages 

  • B1—Denotes the prepubertal breast. At this infantile stage only the papilla is elevated.  
  • B2—Denotes thelarche. The breast buds are palpable, areola enlarges and the breast is elevated like a small mound. 
  • B3—There is further enlargement of the breast and its areola without separation of its contours. 
  • B4—Preferential growth of the areola and nipple leads to formation of a secondary mound over the mound of the breast. 
  • B5—Formation of the mature adult breast. There is recession of the areola into the general contour of the breast because of greater growth of the breast tissue. 

Pubic Hair Development  

The stages of pubic hair growth are as follows:  

  •  P1—prepubertal stage when there are no coarse pubic hair present, the vellus hair present over the pubic area are similar to the ones seen over the abdominal wall. 
  • P2—pubarche denotes the appearance of long or slightly curved and pigmented hair sparsely over the labia.  
  • P3—darker, coarser and curly hair are seen spread over the mons pubis.  
  • P4—the preadult stage when thick dark growths of curly hair are seen covering the area short of the inverted triangle.

questions.text: Identify the structures marked as B in the histological image of the cerebellar cortex as shown in the image below
questions.solution:
The cerebellar cortex has a uniform structure in all parts of the cerebellum. It may be divided into three layers:

(a)The Molecular layer (most superficial).

(b) Purkinje cell layer.

(c) Granular layer, which rests on white matter.

  • The Purkinje cell layer is unusual in that it contains only one layer of neurons. The cell bodies of these neurons are large and flask shaped. The cells are evenly spaced. Dendrite arises from the ‘neck’ of the ‘flask’ and passes ‘upwards’ into the molecular layer.
  • Granule cells are very small, numerous, spherical neurons that occupy the greater part of the granular layer. The spaces not occupied by them are called cerebellar islands. These islands are occupied by special synaptic structures called glomeruli.
  • Golgi neurons are large, stellate cells lying in the granular layer, just deep to the Purkinje cells. Their dendrites enter the molecular layer, where they branch profusely, and synapse with the parallel fibres.

questions.text: Most common thyroid malignancy in iodine sufficient areas
questions.solution:
Most common thyroid malignancy in iodine sufficient areas is Papillary Carcinoma of thyroid.

Thyroid malignancy:

  • Most common primary thyroid malignancy – Papillary Ca
  • Most common thyroid malignancy associated with radiation - Papillary Ca
  • Most common thyroid malignancy in iodine sufficient areas – Papillary Ca
  • Most common malignancy of thyroid associated with lymphatic spread – Papillary Ca
  • Most common thyroid malignancy associated with MNG - Follicular Ca
  • Most common thyroid malignancy associated with blood and bone metastasis – Follicular Ca
  • Most common thyroid malignancy associated with amyloid - Medullary Ca

  • Most aggressive thyroid malignancy with worst prognosis - Anaplastic Ca

Papillary carcinoma:

  • 2:1 female-to-male ratio
  • The mean age at presentation is 30 to 40 years.
  • Most common type of thyroid carcinoma in children and in iodine sufficient areas

questions.text: In a heart patient the worst prognosis during pregnancy is seen in
questions.solution:
Mild to moderate aortic stenosis is tolerated but severe aortic stenosis is life-threatening with decreased preload.

It is important to remember, stenotic heart diseases have a worse prognosis than regurgitant lesions.

Among stenotic heart diseases, aortic stenosis will have the worst prognosis, then mitral stenosis and then pulmonary stenosis. (Alphabetical order)

Congenital heart disease and mitral valve prolapse have the best prognosis.

Option A mitral regurgitation:

Mitral regurgitation is well tolerated during pregnancy probably due to decreased systemic vascular resistance which actually reduces the regurgitation. Heart failure only rarely develops during pregnancy.

Option B mitral valve prolapse:

Pregnant women with mitral valve prolapse rarely have cardiac complications. In fact, pregnancy induced hypovolemia may improve alignment of mitral valve.

Option D pulmonary stenosis

Pulmonary stenosis is well tolerated during pregnancy and rarely causes any complications. Severe pulmonary stenosis is associated with right heart failure and atrial arrhythmias.

questions.text: Which of the following is a pure pharmacokinetic booster without inherent antiviral activity co-administered with other agents in HIV infection?
questions.solution:

questions.text: A 45-year-old man presents with abdominal pain. Examination reveals slate grey skin pigmentation and hepatomegaly. His liver biopsy shows golden-yellow granules in periportal hepatocytes.  Histopathological staining with Prussian Blue is shown in the image below.  All are true about this condition except:
questions.solution:
The image shows Prussian blue-stained section of liver tissue showing extensive haemosiderin deposition stained blue. The most likely diagnosis is hereditary haemochromatosis. In haemochromatosis, the testes may be small and atrophic, secondary to a derangement in the hypothalamic-pituitary axis resulting in reduced gonadotropin and testosterone levels.

Hemochromatosis is caused by excessive iron absorption, most of which is deposited in parenchymal organs such as the liver and pancreas, followed by heart, joints, and endocrine organs.

When hemochromatosis results from an inherited disorder, it is referred to as hereditary hemochromatosis. In hereditary hemochromatosis, HFE, HJV, or TFR2 gene mutations reduce hepcidin synthesis. Due to decreased hepcidin-ferroportin interaction, ferroportin activity and iron efflux from enterocytes increases, giving rise to systemic iron overload.

Fully developed cases exhibit
(1) micronodular cirrhosis in all patients
(2) diabetes mellitus in 75% to 80% of patients
(3) abnormal skin pigmentation in 75% to 80% of patients

Symptoms usually first appear in the fourth to fifth decades of life in men and later in women.

The manifestations of classic hemochromatosis include hepatomegaly, abdominal pain, hypogonadism, abnormal skin pigmentation (particularly in sunexposed areas), deranged glucose homeostasis or diabetes mellitus due to destruction of pancreatic islets, cardiac dysfunction (arrhythmias, cardiomyopathy), and atypical arthritis. A significant cause of death is hepatocellular carcinoma.

questions.text: The following image shows:
questions.solution:
The above image is of a joule burn which is specific and diagnostic of electric burns and is found at the point of entry.  

Joule burn is a specific and diagnostic of contact with electricity and is found at the point of entry of the current. It is seen in accidents with high-tension currents. It is an endogenous thermal burn due to the heat generated in the body from electricity. These marks are round or oval, shallow craters, 1-2 cm in diameter, and raised borders around part or the whole of their circumference.
The crater floor is lined by pale flattened skin. The presence of an areola of blanched skin is seen at the periphery of the joule burn, which survives death and is pathognomonic of electrical damage.

Other important features of electrical injuries:

  • Flash / Spark burns - results when there is a high voltage electrical injury and contact between metal and skin is loose. It is an exogenous burn, keratin melts in the skin producing brownish keratin nodules with pale areola. Very high voltage currents produce massive destruction of tissue with loss of extremities and rupture of organs. 
  • Crocodile burns - multiple nodules on the skin due to high voltage electrical injury over a large body surface. 
  • Bone pearls or wax drippings - heat generated by the current may melt the calcium phosphate which is seen in X-rays of limbs as typical round dense foci. 

Other options:

Option A: Soot-soiling occurs from the person holding a shotgun barrel.

  • In tight flesh contact wounds, soot soiling, and muzzle marks are uncommon. If there is loose contact or clothes are interposed, there may be soiling or muzzle marks.
  • In a case involving a close-range shotgun injury, if a victim catches the barrel of the gun, there may be soot-soling of the hands.

Option B: Frost Bite:

Below is the image of frostbite. It occurs when the body is exposed to cold temperatures (-2.5° C), is only produced during life, and cannot be caused postmortem.

Option D: Scalding: Scalds are due to exposure to wet heat like hot water or steam (image shown below).

questions.text: Which of the following statements regarding listeria monocytogenes infection is false?

choices.text: Laboratory isolation involves cold enrichment technique
Neonatal infections occur only during passage through the infected birth canal
Invasion of the brainstem results in a characteristic severe rhombencephalitis
A nonspecific febrile illness with myalgia is a common presentation in pregnant women.

questions.solution:
Neonatal infections can arise either from infection during delivery or from an in-utero infection. In either case, the prognosis is poor.

About other options:

Option A: Listeria growth occurs if stored in thioglycolate broth at 40C and subcultures are done at weekly intervals for 1-6 months (known as cold enrichment technique).

Option C: L. monocytogenes can directly invade the brain parenchyma, leading to either cerebritis or focal abscess. Invasion of the brainstem results in a characteristic severe rhombencephalitis.

Option D: The usual presentation of listeriosis in pregnancy is a nonspecific acute or subacute febrile illness with myalgias, arthralgias, backache, and headache.

questions.text: Which of the following is unlikely to be seen in a patient with aortic stenosis?

choices.text: Rapidly rising pulse with sudden collapse
Lateral displacement of the apical impulse

questions.solution:
Aortic stenosis (AS) shows a slow-rising pulse with a delayed peak — this is known as pulsus parvus et tardus. Rapidly rising pulse with sudden collapse (option B) is seen in aortic regurgitation (AR) — this is known as water hammer pulse.

Other examination findings in patients with AS include:

  • A thrill may be palpable on the carotid arteries, more often on the left side.
  • Lateral displacement of the apical impulse (option D).
  • Ejection systolic murmur which increases in intensity to reach a peak towards the middle of ejection (known as crescendo-decrescendo pattern), and ends right before aortic valve closure.
  • Aortic valve closure occurs after pulmonary valve closure, leading to paradoxical splitting of S2 — splitting of S2 in expiration, not in inspiration.

questions.text: Damage control surgery refers to ________

choices.text: Maximum possible surgical intervention done immediately
Minimal intervention done to stabilize the patient and do the definitive surgery later
Done to control damage during surgery

questions.solution:
Damage control surgery refers to the concept of limiting the initial operative interventions, in the unstable trauma patient, to those maneuvers that are immediately lifesaving (e.g., control of surgical hemorrhage, control of continued fecal contamination).
The physiologic rationale for damage control surgery relates to the metabolic consequences of extensive blood loss and blood and fluid replacement.

questions.text:
Which of the following does not occur as the blood passes through muscle tissue capillaries?

Hb: Hemoglobin

choices.text: Left shift of Hb:O2 dissociation curve

questions.solution:
As the blood passes through the capillaries, there is a right shift of the oxygen hemoglobin dissociation curve (not left).

Gaseous and nutrient exchange occur between the capillaries and the tissues. At the tissue level, this leads to higher concentration of CO2, less concentration of oxygen, and lower pH (option D). This higher CO2 concentration and lower pH shifts the oxygen hemoglobin dissociation curve to the right. This in turn reduces the affinity of hemoglobin towards oxygen and thereby releases more oxygen to the tissue to facilitate gas exchange.

Other options:

Options A and C: As blood passes through systemic capillaries , there is net pressure towards the adjacent tissues leading to absorption of water and in return toxins are returned to the capillaries leading to increased protein content and increased hematocrit.

questions.text: What is the value of gas constant in the equation ΔG0 = −RT ln Keq?
questions.solution:

Equation, ΔG0 = −RT ln Keq, illustrates the relationship between Keq and ΔG0

Keq= Equilibrium constant

ΔG0 =Change in free energy that accompanies transition from the standard state, one-molar concentrations of substrates and products, to equilibrium.

R = Gas constant (1.98 Kcal/mol°K or 8.31 J/mol°K)

T = Absolute temperature in degrees Kelvin.

questions.text: The most common histologic picture in cases of rapidly progressing glomerulonephritis is:

questions.text: False statement about Massive hemoptysis is:

choices.text: Most common source of bleeding is bronchial arteries
In unstable patient rigid bronchoscopy is done to identify the lesion
First investigation to  be done is CT scan

questions.solution:
Massive hemoptysis:

  • It is defined as greater than 500 to 600 mL of blood loss from the lungs in 24 hours.
  • Most common source of bleeding is bronchial arteries in 90% of cases.
  • The major causes of massive hemoptysis are :
    • Tuberculosis
    • Bronchiectasis
    • cancer.
  • Diagnosis and treatment of massive hemoptysis typically include:
    • Chest x ray and emergency rigid bronchoscopy.
    • Flexible bronchoscopy is usually inadequate for treatment of hemoptysis
    • If source of bleeding ios not identified on the plain Xray film, CT of the chest can be done
  • Mortality is high with urgent or emergency resection.
  • Conservative management may consist of:
    • Maintaining a functional and patent airway
    • Bronchoscopy,
    • Clearing the airway of blood
    • Cough suppression (with codeine)
    • Monitoring until stabilized.
    • Angiographic catheterization for massive hemoptysis may be considered in patients with hemoptysis

questions.text: All are true regarding mesothelioma except:

questions.text: The stability of the ankle joint is maintained by all of the following except:

choices.text: Close approximation of the articular surfaces

questions.solution:
The stability of the ankle joint is maintained by the following:

  • Close interlocking of the articular surfaces of the distal tibis-fibula and the talus.
  • Fibrous capsule
  • Strong collateral ligaments: Deltoid ligament (medial collateral ligament), lateral collateral ligament, syndesmotic ligament
  • Tendons that cross the joint
  • Also, gravity, muscle action and ground reaction forces provide dynamic stability.
  • Stability requires the continuous action of soleus assisted by gastrocnemius; it increases when leaning forwards, and decreases when leaning backwards.

questions.text: The skin biopsy specimen, stained with H&E, when observed under a microscope appears as shown in the given image. The appearance is seen in which of the following fungal infections?
questions.solution:
The given image shows asteroid bodies characteristic of Sporotrichosis. They are rounded or oval basophilic, yeast-like bodies of 3-5 µm in diameter, with rays of an eosinophilic substance radiating from the yeast cell. The yeast is cigar-shaped and this phenomenon is known as Splendore-Hoeppli phenomenon.

Sporotrichosis:

  • It is caused by Sporothrix schenckii (Sporotrichum).
  • It is a chronic infection involving the cutaneous, subcutaneous and lymphatic tissue leading to the formation of indolent ulcers commonly encountered frequently among gardeners, forest workers, etc.
  • From the lesions in the skin and subcutaneous tissue, the infection can spread via the lymphatic channels to the lymph nodes. This condition is known as “lymphocutaneous sporotrichosis”.

Note: Asteroid bodies are also seen in Sarcoidosis. Those are irregular, star-shaped inclusions seen in multinucleate giant cells.

questions.text: Which of the following anomalies occurs due to the failure of the fusion of the two pancreatic buds during the development of the fetus?
questions.solution:
• Pancreatic divisum is a congenital anomaly in the anatomy of the ducts of the pancreas in which a single pancreatic duct is not formed, but rather remains as two distinct dorsal and ventral ducts due to the failure of fusion of the two pancreatic buds.
  • In most of the patients the condition is asymptomatic, however, few individuals may develop symptoms which commonly include abdominal pain, nausea, vomiting, and may also develop acute and chronic pancreatitis.

questions.text: The liver biopsy in acute hepatitis due to hepatitis B virus is likely to show all of the following except:
questions.solution:
• Ground glass hepatocytes are a feature of chronic hepatitis due to hepatitis B virus.
  • Biopsy features of acute viral hepatitis include spotty or focal necrosis, lobular hepatitis, ballooning degeneration and mononuclear cell infiltration.

questions.text: The transport of acyl-CoA for oxidation using a shuttle involves formation of which intermediate?
questions.solution:
Transport of acyl-CoA for oxidation using a shuttle involves formation of Acyl-carnitine.

Fatty acids must first be converted to an active intermediatebefore they can be catabolized.

This is the only step degradation of a fatty acid that requires energy from ATP.

Enzyme involved in fatty acid transfer across membrane:

Related Pearl: Enzymes Involved in Fatty acid Transfer Across Mitochondrial membrane

Enzyme

Site of action

Action

Acyl-CoA synthetase (Thiokinase)

Outer mitochondrial membrane

Converts free fatty acid into Acyl CoA

Carnitine palmitoyl transferase-I

Outer mitochondrial membrane

Transfers long-chain acyl group from CoA to carnitine, forming acylcarnitine.

Carnitine-acylcarnitine translocase

Inner  mitochondrial membrane

Help Acylcarnitine to penetrate the inner membrane

Carnitine palmitoyl transferase-II

Inner  mitochondrial membrane

Along with carnitine palmitoyl transferase I oxidizes long-chain fatty acids in the mitochondria.

questions.text: The second most common mode of death in fatal child abuse around the world is:
questions.solution:
The second most common mode of death in fatal child abuse around the world is rupture of an abdominal viscus.

The most common mode of death in fatal child abuse is head trauma.

questions.text: Identify the instrument in the image given below:
questions.solution:
The image depicts Goligher retractor.

Goligher retractor:

  • This is a self-retaining retractor used in operations on the sigmoid colon and rectum, such as anterior resection and upper end of abdominoperineal resection.
  • Once the abdomen has been opened and laparotomy performed, the patient is placed head down and all the small bowel is packed to the upper end of the abdomen.
  • The retractor is then inserted with the side blades to separate the edges of the abdominal wall.
  • The central blade is then inserted to keep the small bowel well tucked away from the operation site.
  • All three blades come in different widths to fit in with the patient’s build.

questions.text: The biochemical oxygen demand (BOD) indicates:
questions.solution:
• The biochemical oxygen demand (BOD) is the standard test used as an indicator of organic content in sewage.
  • It is defined as the amount of oxygen absorbed by a sample of sewage during a specified period (generally 5 days), at a specified temperature (generally 20℃) for the aerobic destruction or use of organic matter by living microorganisms.
  • A high BOD indicates a high content of easily degradable, organic material while a low BOD indicates the presence of content that is not easily degradable, low volume of organic matter or measurement problems.
